Graphical abstract Modifying etching reaction from MAX phase tunes conductivity and surface termination of 2D MXene, construction of 3D MXene modulates specific surface area, interlayer spacing and ion transport pathway, optimization enhances electrochemical performance of MXene electrodes. MXene has been the limelight for studies on electrode active materials, aiming at developing supercapacitors with boosted energy density to meet the emerging influx of wearable and portable electronic devices. Despite its various desirable properties including intrinsic flexibility, high specific surface area, excellent metallic conductivity and unique abundance of surface functionalities, its full potential for electrochemical performance is hindered by the notorious restacking phenomenon of MXene nanosheets. Ascribed to its two-dimensional (2D) nature and surface functional groups, inevitable Van der Waals interactions drive the agglomeration of nanosheets, ultimately reducing the exposure of electrochemically active sites to the electrolyte, as well as severely lengthening electrolyte ion transport pathways. As a result, energy and power density deteriorate, limiting the application versatility of MXene-based supercapacitors. Constructing 3D architectures using 2D nanosheets presents as a straightforward yet ingenious approach to mitigate the fatal flaws of MXene. However, the sheer number of distinct methodologies reported, thus far, calls for a systematic review that unravels the rationale behind such 3D MXene structural designs. Herein, this review aims to serve this purpose while also scrutinizing the structure–property relationship to correlate such structural modifications to their ensuing electrochemical performance enhancements. Besides, the physicochemical properties of MXene play fundamental roles in determining the effective charge storage capabilities of 3D MXene-based electrodes. This largely depends on different MXene synthesis techniques and synthesis condition variations, hence, elucidated in this review as well. Lastly, the challenges and perspectives for achieving viable commercialization of MXene-based supercapacitor electrodes are highlighted. Keywords MXene 3D architectures Synthesis design Supercapacitor Energy storage 1 Introduction The proliferation of the Internet of Things technologies is inevitable to facilitate convenient and extensive control over various devices and machineries to aid with the increasingly complex human lifestyle. Amidst the global endeavor to normalize clean and sustainable energy, these intelligent electronics are designed to be highly portable and decentralized, self-powered by means of renewable energy (RE) harvesting devices such as photovoltaic and triboelectric nanogenerators. Advanced energy storage systems (ESSs) are imperative to regulate power input and output in these devices. Lithium-ion batteries (LIB) have been the quintessential ESSs for portable electronics but the geographically scattered and impending depletion of lithium mineral resources declined their future prospects. Despite numerous studies directed towards realizing naturally abundant metal-ion batteries such as sodium-ion and potassium-ion batteries, sluggish charge-transfer and lacklustre cyclic stability remain critical problems to be tackled due to migration and insertion kinetics of bulkier Na+ and K+ ions [1,2]. Hence, supercapacitors play an irreplaceable role in enabling reliable storage for energy scavenged from intermittent RE sources due to their extended cycle life (up to 100,000 cycles) compared to batteries (up to 10,000 cycles) [3,4]. To minimize the weight and volume occupancy of these portable ESSs, energy density becomes a crucial performance parameter in gravimetric, areal, and volumetric terms, which is especially lacking for supercapacitors. The study of supercapacitor electrode active materials to explore novel syntheses, formulations, and combinations targeted at augmenting energy density is, therefore, widely prevalent. Active materials nanostructuring and surface property engineering have been effective strategies to amplify their surface area and electrochemical activity, respectively, for enhanced charge storage performance [5,6]. MXene has, thus, garnered substantial research attention due to its intrinsic properties, possessing geometrically high surface area and highly functionalizable surfaces. MXene is an emerging family of 2D transitional metal carbides or nitrides with the general formula of M n +1X n Tx. M is an early transition metal (Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Y, Zr, Nb, Mo, Hf, Ta, W); X is carbon or nitrogen; n is an integer between 1 and 4; Tx stands for the surface functional groups which include oxygen (O), hydroxyl (OH) and fluoride terminations (-F) [7]. Appreciable appeal for MXene-based supercapacitor electrodes is attributed to its intrinsic metallic conductivity up to 20,000 S cm−1 and metal oxide-like redox-active surface that leads to exceptional pseudocapacitive behavior with a theoretical specific capacitance up to 1,116 F g−1 [8,9]. Numerous work managed to capitalize on its nanoscale mechanical flexibility and fabricated highly flexible free-standing films. These films readily served as supercapacitor electrodes via simple vacuum filtration of MXene dispersions, proving its versatility in supercapacitor applications [10,11]. Furthermore, MXene offers high degree of tunability in its physicochemical properties. This is done by modifying its synthesis technique and precursor selection, as well as kinetically controlling the synthesis process by varying the reaction temperature, duration and reactant concentration. Facile tweaking of MXene qualities and characteristics such as electrical conductivity, nanosheet flake sizes, and surface terminating elements is consequently beneficial to facilitate high-rate, high-volume electrochemical energy storage of MXene-based supercapacitors. Concomitantly, it is equally essential to tackle the Achilles’ heel of MXene for ion transfer and charge storage purposes. Attributed to its 2D layered nanostructure and abundance of surface terminations, strong Van der Waals interactions and hydrogen bonding between adjacent layers inevitably induces the well-known restacking and aggregation issue of 2D MXene [12,13]. This severely hampers the accessibility of electrolyte ions to electrochemically active sites, reducing the probability of surface redox reactions and ultimately degrading its pseudocapacitance [14]. Hence, microstructure and macrostructure modification strategies of 2D MXene are widely sought-after solutions for constructing 3D MXene architectures with enlarged specific surface area along with improved electrolyte interaction, further boosting its electrochemical performance. Hitherto, the fascinating inherent properties of MXene have amassed a vast number of studies developing multifaceted methodologies for constructing novel 3D architectures. However, the expansion of such studies is gradually approaching a bottleneck. Unidimensional strategies involving a single structural formation process, create 3D features with dimensions of uniformly similar magnitudes, limiting the final structural designability. This limitation is faced with an inevitable trade-off where large generated pore sizes lead to good rate performance but poor specific capacitance, and vice versa for small pore sizes. Currently, there are inadequate existing reviews that scrutinize reported 3D architectures in such aspects. Consequently, there lacks a clear future direction of such studies in order to realize structures of higher complexity for eliminating the performance trade-off. Herein, this review aims to provide a comprehensive overview of constructing high-performance 3D MXene architectures, particularly encompassing the rationale behind exploring diverse 2D MXene synthesis techniques, conducting precise synthesis process optimizations and introducing 3D architectures through advanced structural modification strategies. First, the charge storage mechanism of MXene-based supercapacitors is elucidated. Various synthesis techniques, categorizable as conventional, emerging, and innovative techniques, are highlighted along with their subsequent impacts on the characteristics of the synthesized MXene. The effects of synthesis parameters, including the selection of MAX phase precursors, alteration of synthesis conditions, and modification of surface terminations, are then scrutinized accordingly. This is followed by underscoring state-of-the-art dimensional evolutions of 2D MXene into 3D structures, the thought process behind designing such structures, and the improvements it imparts to the electrochemical performance of the final electrode. The concept of unidimensional and multidimensional architecturing is exclusively introduced to explicate the progression of existing strategies in terms of structural complexity and its ability to simultaneously achieve high specific capacitance and rate performance. Lastly, challenges and future perspectives of pushing the capacitive capability limits of MXene-based supercapacitors via 3D architecturing strategies, as well as their commercialization are summarized to direct concentrated research efforts towards addressing these impending issues. 2 Charge storage mechanism of MXene-based supercapacitors Supercapacitors are generally categorized into two main types, which are electric-double layer capacitors (EDLCs) and pseudocapacitors. They are characterized by their charge storage mechanisms, which are highly dependent on the choice of active materials. The charge–discharge process of EDLC is based on rapid electrosorption of ions driven by electrostatic attraction, in which ions in the electrolyte migrate into the pores of electrodes with opposite charges during charging and desorb from the pores during discharging. The ion arrangement to the different poles causes the build-up of opposite polarity charge pairs at the electrode/electrolyte interfaces, forming the Helmholtz double layer [15]. EDLC has power density that is considerably high due to its mechanistic ion adsorption–desorption that is merely a physical, and therefore rapid process. With neither chemical reactions nor compositional changes occurring in an EDLC, its charge storage mechanisms are highly reversible, allowing more superior cyclic stability than electrochemical batteries by several orders of magnitude [16]. Pseudocapacitor stores charges electrochemically via faradaic redox reactions occurring between electrode and electrolyte. Unlike the physical nature of EDLC mechanism that limits its energy density, the potential to improve the charge storage ability of a pseudocapacitive electrode is much more promising as it strongly depends on the chemical affinity between the electrode active materials and the ions adsorbed on the electrode surface [17]. There are three possible pseudocapacitive mechanisms, including intercalation pseudocapacitance, where ions intercalate into the layers of active material, followed by subsequent faradaic charge transfer without any crystallographic phase changes [18]. Redox pseudocapacitance refers to ions undergoing simultaneous faradaic charge transfer and electrochemical adsorption onto the active material surfaces [19]. Underpotential deposition is an uncommon mechanism, where metal ions form an absorption monolayer on a dissimilar metal surface with a much higher redox potential [20]. Fascinatingly, the charge storage process in MXene is not governed by a single mechanism, and it is rather interchangeable, determined by the magnitude of electrostatic potential difference applied across the electrode/electrolyte interface as well as the type of electrolyte ions and surface terminations [21]. MXene is likely to exemplify EDLC capacitance in H+-deficient environment, such as in neutral (e.g., K2SO4 [22], and MgSO4 [23]) and basic (e.g., NaOH [24], KOH [25]) electrolytes. Conversely, its charge storage is preponderantly underpinned by pseudocapacitive behaviors when deploying acidic electrolyte (e.g., 3 M H2SO4 solution) [26]. This is corroborated by the well-known MXene pseudocapacitive mechanism, acknowledged by numerous works, in which H+ ions in the electrolyte undergo highly reversible protonation/deprotonation with -O terminations of MXene [21,27]. The lack of H+ ions in neutral and basic electrolytes has denied pseudocapacitive charge storage, rather, electrolyte ions tend to be encapsulated in strong hydration shells that acts as a dielectric, preventing orbital hybridization between the ions and MXene surface terminations. As a consequence, charge storage stems from the segregation of hydrated ions to different poles, forming electric double layers (Fig. 1 a) [28,29]. CV profiles recorded by MXene operating in neutral and basic electrolytes; therefore, display pseudorectangular shapes (Fig. 1b and c) [30]. On the contrary, MXene in acidic electrolyte, H2SO4 in particular, exhibits a combination of EDLC, intercalation pseudocapacitance and redox pseudocapacitance. The proportion of occurrence for each mechanism largely depends on the polarization voltage and surface termination composition. Since only -O terminations instigate protonation reactions, MXene that is heavily decorated with other terminations will tend to display EDLC-dominant characteristics. Sufficiently negative voltage applied is required to overcome the adsorption potential of intercalated positive hydronium ions (natural state of H+ ions in aqueous environment) [31]. When this happens, the hydration shells are negated and orbital hybridization allow the direct adsorption of hydronium ions with O termination species, giving rise to intercalation pseudocapacitance (Fig. 1d) [21]. At increasingly negative potentials, O terminations are accumulatively converted to OH terminations via continuous adsorption of hydronium ions, electrostatic repulsion from identically charged OH terminals expands the MXene interlayer, causing volume fluctuations (Fig. 1e) [32]. As the interlayer spacing continues to expand, the MXene surface is increasingly exposed such that ion intercalation is no longer required, instead the ions undergo rapid surface redox and the resulting changes in the oxidation states of “M” layer contribute towards redox pseudocapacitance [33]. The diverse nature of charge storage mechanism displayed by MXene in H2SO4 electrolyte has unveiled the potential of MXene as a promising pseudocapacitive electrode material with enhanced current response, indicating greater amount of stored charge (Fig. 1f) [34]. Quantitatively, it is noticeable that the specific capacitance of Ti3C2Tx MXene in acidic H2SO4 electrolyte is 239.8 F g−1, which is nearly six-times higher compared to the neutral Na2SO4, LiCl and MgCl2 electrolyte at negative potential region. Conversely, MXene is mainly showing EDLC properties under positive potentials due to the bounded pseudocapacitive charge storage caused by anodic oxidation. The anodic oxidation of MXene, particularly Ti3C2Tx, stands as a significant concern that deeply impacting the cyclic stability and charge storage capability as supercapacitor electrode. The Ti3C2Tx electrode is susceptible to oxidation at anodic potentials, attributed to their facile electron loss and the subsequent formation of a TiO2 in aqueous solutions [35]. Unfortunately, this oxidation process is irreversible, leading to diminished electrochemical activity compared to the pristine material. This enduring change in electrochemical behavior extends beyond surface composition alterations, surface Ti atoms connected to O are removed, resulting in TiO2- x F x formation, and exposed C atoms likely form CC bonds [36]. Continued oxidation and TiO2 formation led to emergence of insulative oxide layer that enlarges the electrochemically inactive sites, and ultimately, causes substantial capacitance losses. Moreover, the anodic potential initiates the dissolution of Ti3C2Tx material after the TiO2 forming complex with F− ions, and dissolute in aqueous electrolyte. This will eventually reduce the electrochemically active site compared to the initial pristine Ti3C2Tx. From the macroscopic perspective, noticeable layer detachment can usually be found at the Ti3C2Tx after several charge/discharge cycles which leads to losses in active material and cease in capacitance [37]. Therefore, it is necessary to hybridize MXene with foreign materials to create stable composites at positive potentials, thereby mitigating the irreversible oxidation problem and enhancing the capacitance, stability, and energy density of the fabricated electrode. To combine the features of high-power density from EDLCs and high-energy density from pseudocapacitors, hybrid supercapacitors has thus been developed. One of the methods to do this is by employing dissimilar electrodes, one EDLC and one pseudocapacitive, forming an asymmetric hybrid supercapacitor (Fig. 1g) [38]. This kind of hybrid supercapacitor operates with faradaic and non-faradaic processes combined. An asymmetric Ti3C2Tx-CNT supercapacitor suggests a widen potential window up to 1.6 V, which ultimately enables the delivery of high specific capacitance of 176 F g−1 and energy density of 62 W h kg−1 at a scan rate of 2 mV s−1 (Fig. 1h) [39]. CNT serves as the EDLC electrode, which is designed with superior porosity to maximize the contact surface for ion adsorption–desorption, whereas MXene provides pseudocapacitance through reversible redox reactions [40,41]. Vice versa, MXene can also serve the EDLC role in non-acidic electrolytes and be coupled with pseudocapacitive materials such as conducting polymers and metal oxides. Beside electrode hybridization, the flexible charge storage nature of MXene nanosheets allows its compositing with either EDLC or pseudocapacitive materials into symmetric supercapacitor. Supporting materials can act as spacers to expand the MXene interlayers, enlarging its active surface area [42,43]. Such MXene-based nanocomposites (e.g., V2C MXene-PANI and MXene-MoO3) exemplified enhanced charge transfer kinetics that resulted in a high capacitance of 783.4 F g−1 at 5 mV s−1 (Fig. 1i), on top of improved structural stability [44]. Delves into the perspective of improved structural stability, compositing MXene with PANI promotes higher resistance to anodic oxidation at positive potential region. This is evident by the high-rate capability up to 65.4% from the current density of 1 to 1,000 A g−1 at the positive potentials (0.0–0.5 V). Eventually, this allows the MXene composite electrode to operate at wider operating potential that results in boosted energy density when assembling into a full cell [45]. To sum up, understanding the charge storage mechanisms of MXene in various electrolyte and further research into MXene-based hybrid materials is crucial to the development of high-performance supercapacitors with improved energy storage capacity. 3 2D MXene synthesis techniques Synthesis strategies of 2D MXene can be merely classified into bottom-up and top-down methods. Chemical vapor deposition (CVD), templating method and plasma enhanced pulsed laser deposition are among the many bottom-up methods explored [46,47]. They principally involve stringently controlled atom-by-atom deposition in layered configuration to construct individual MXene nanosheets, thus allowing a high degree of customizability in the MXene synthesized with regard to morphology, crystal size, crystallinity, and thickness [48]. For example, the recently reported zirconium-based MXenes, Zr2CCl2 and Zr2CBr2 are directly synthesized through CVD method by reacting CH4 and ZrCl4 or ZrBr4 with Zr foil at 975 °C [49]. In addition, both titanium carbide-based and nitride-based MXene, namely Ti2CCl2 and Ti2NCl2 can be synthesized following the similar routes. The CVD-derived MXenes can be synthesized by reacting the Ti metal with gaseous precursors such as CH4 for carbon source, and N2 for nitrogen source, under different reaction temperatures. The synthesized MXenes are perpendicularly aligned to the substrate, allowing efficient ion transfer. Consequently, multiple works have employed CVD to obtain large area, highly crystalline MXene flakes with low defect concentration. However, the proposed CVD routes demand reaction temperatures close to 1,000 °C. MXene crystals are also generally grown in-situ on substrates of other materials; post-processing is necessary to extract the crystals and obtain pure MXene, adding meticulosity to supercapacitor electrode fabrication [50,51]. Bottom-up methods, therefore, encounter a severe bottleneck in their process scalability for commercialization due to their requirements for exceedingly complex operations and harsh synthesis conditions, eventually leading to high cost and poor production efficiency. In contrast, top-down MXene synthesis involves a single element being selectively etched from a ternary transition metal compound via wet processing, mainly relying on chemical interactions between reactants under external stimuli such as elevated temperatures and energy waves. Thus, scaling up the synthesis process is rather straightforward by methodically manipulating the reactant compositions and stimuli intensity. In fact, it has been proven feasible to scale up Ti3C2Tx MXene production by fiftyfold without modification of chemical reactant ratios, reaction time, and temperature [52]. Moreover, top-down methods are practicable under much milder operation conditions that are liberally moderated compared to bottom-up methods. Along with the increasingly inexpensive precursor materials that are widely attainable, top-down etching methods present reliable sources of MXene with high yield, readily integrated into supercapacitor electrode fabrication [53,54]. Researchers have been continuously inventing novel top-down approaches to discover the best performing synthesis route in terms of reactant cost, reactant toxicity, safety, operating condition requirements and quality of the synthesized MXene. These are categorizable into conventional, emerging and innovative approaches, illustrated in Fig. 2 . The performances of the conventional, emerging and innovative etching approaches are listed in Table S1 in the supplementary materials. 3.1 Conventional approaches Conventional approaches include well-established methods that are already widely prevalent in ESS studies. 2D MXene is mostly derived from polycrystalline nanolaminates of ternary carbides and nitrides in a layered hexagonal structure called MAX phases [55]. The general equation of MAX phase is M n +1AX n , where M and X were identified above, A is a group IIIA or IVA species. The weaker MA bonds relative to MX bonds ease the selective removal of the A layer via acid etching [56]. The pioneering synthesis of Ti3C2Tx MXene was performed by immersing Ti3AlC2 powder in 50% HF at room temperature for 2 h [57]. HF etching was proven to be a consistent method to remove Al layers from their respective MAX phases to obtain various other MXene like V2CTx, Nb4C3Tx, Ta4C3Tx and Zr3C2Tx [58–61]. To avoid handling high concentrations of extremely hazardous HF acid, in-situ HF etching was reported by dissolving Ti3AlC2 powder in an aqueous solution of 5 M lithium fluoride (LiF) in 6 M hydrochloric acid (HCl) at 40 °C for 45 h [62]. Later on, the minimally intensive layer delamination (MILD) method was developed to optimize the molar composition, where the reaction was carried out in 12 M LiF/9 M HCl at room temperature [63]. The as-synthesized MXene has larger flake sizes and fewer surface defects, which are favorable for charge storage in supercapacitors. As evidenced in a nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) study, MXene synthesized via MILD method exhibits four times lesser -F terminations than that synthesized from HF etching. Instead, they are replaced with -Cl terminations introduced by HCl [64]. Ascribed to the larger ionic radius of Cl− compared to F−, the steric effect from -Cl terminations effectively expands the interlayer spacing. The increased surface area exposed to electrolyte ameliorates ion accessibility towards concealed macropores and redox-active sites, thereby facilitating higher degree of ion adsorption and redox reactions [65]. The enlarged interlayer spacing also allows Li+ ions and water molecules to act as intercalants, facilitating facile delamination into MXene nanosheets by gentle shaking. On the other hand, HF requires the use of organic intercalants such as dimethyl sulfoxide and tetraalkylammonium hydroxide (TMAOH), followed by ultrasonication for complete delamination [63]. This tedious procedure produces smaller MXene flakes with higher defects, diminishing the overall electrical conductivity. It was also revealed that LiF/HCl etched MXene yields higher content of O than F and OH terminations [64]. The dominant O terminations increase the probability of protonation-deprotonation reactions and effectively improve pseudocapacitance [66]. Recognizing the fact that F terminations are undesirable in the sense that they are redox inactive, they pose as the main hurdle towards realizing MXene with improved pseudocapacitive behavior. In response, there is a surge in the research on a multiplicity of different novel synthesis approaches, principally pivoting on the elimination of -F terminations and maximization of O terminations via fluoride-free techniques. 3.2 Emerging approaches Emerging approaches refer to relatively new methods gaining increasing attention owing to their capability to synthesize fluoride-free MXene-based supercapacitors which stands out from conventional HF etching. These emerging methods include alkali etching, molten salt etching, halogen/interhalogen-based etching, and electrochemical etching, as summarized in Fig. 3 . The mentioned techniques have historically found applications in fields such as semiconductor manufacturing [67], metallurgy [68] and photovoltaics [69]. These methods do not require fluoride-containing etchant, unlike conventional HF etching that highly relies on the strong affinity of fluorine towards “A” layers, which leads to the formation of compounds that can be easily removed. The unique selective etching mechanisms of these methods are mainly based on alternative etchants that serves similar purpose as fluoride-containing etchant, rendering them particularly suited for MXene synthesis. The functioning of alkali etching lies in the amphoteric nature of the “A” layer (i.e., Al and Si) in MAX phase precursors, which enables them to form soluble Al(OH)4 − complexes with alkali etchants. Similar to acid etching, alkali etching can produce carbide-based MXene, but have the exclusive ability to prevent the formation of fluoride terminations that dampens its electrochemical performance [70,71]. The etching process is accomplished by the oxidation of Al followed by the dissolution of Al(OH)4 − in concentrated alkali etchant (e.g., 27.5 M NaOH) at high temperature (e.g., 270 °C). The process yielded Ti3C2Tx MXene with 92 wt% purity alongside abundant O and OH instead of -F terminations and exhibited pseudocapacitive behavior in symmetric orientation. However, the high etching temperature and etchant concentration have limited the scalability of alkali etching. This is inevitable as reducing the etching temperature can lead to a “jamming effect” that forms insoluble Al(OH)3 and AlO(OH) [72]. These compounds cannot be dissolved in alkali and remain in the MAX phase precursor, leading to MXene formation failure. Thus, high etching temperature is applied for alkali etching to promote the transformation of Al(OH)3 and AlO(OH) into dissolvable Al(OH)4 − [73]. On the other hand, reducing the etchant concentration can lead to the undesired formation of sodium-titanate (Na2Ti5O11) owing to the oxidation of Ti in water [74,75]. Molten salt etching, also known as Lewis acidic etching, stands out from conventional HF-etching as it can synthesize both fluoride-free carbide- and nitride-based MXene. The incapability of conventional HF etching for M n +1AN n MAX phase is due to the stronger covalent bonds and stable structure of nitrides, making it less susceptible to be etched by acid alone. Additionally, the M n +1AN n MAX phase has higher formation energy, thus requiring more energy to extract the “A” element [76,77]. A hexagonal Ti3C2Tx MXene can be prepared via microwave-assisted selective etching of the precursor mixture (Lewis acid salts (i.e., ZnCl2, NaCl, and KCl) and Ti3AlC2) in NH4F aqueous solution. The as-prepared MXene has outperformed the conventional HF-etched MXene due to absence of fluoride content, engendering 40% higher specific capacitance under same current density [78]. However, this method is highly energy intensive as it requires high temperature to produce a homogenous molten mixture, thereby limiting the transition from lab scale to mass production. Therefore, it is necessary to consider alternative methods with lower temperature requirements to reduce the risk of material degradation during the process, and promote the ease of production implementation. The halogen/interhalogen-based etching is another thermal-driven process to synthesize MXene, which demands relatively low etching temperatures compared to alkali and molten salt etching. The highly reactive halogens (i.e., Cl2, Br2, and I2) and interhalogen compound (i.e., IBr, and ICl) can react with the “A” layer, thus realizing selective etching to produce MXene. The etching mechanism is based on the dissociation of halogen molecules, forming radicals that prone to react with “A” elements. For instance, the I2 can be employed to etch Al from Ti3AlC2 in anhydrous acetonitrile (CH3CN) by forming AlI3. The produced AlI3 is removed after treatment with HCl, leaving accordion-like Ti3C2Tx [79]. The reaction state of halogen/interhalogen-based etching is essentially dormant at room temperature but increasing the etching temperature from 60 to 100 °C has been proven to reduce the Al content by six-fold and produce MXene with higher purity. However, the temperature requirement becomes less stringent with increasing reactivity of the etchant used. In fact, the selective etching of Al can be achieved at room temperature using Br2 etchant [80]. Another emerging approach is electrochemical etching, that utilizes a two/three-electrodes system to remove the “A” layer from MAX phases precursor through anodic corrosion, thereby forming fluoride-free MXene. The selective etching process is conducted in Cl− containing electrolytes (e.g., HCl, NaCl, FeCl3 and NH4Cl) at a certain voltage. The MAX phase precursor is the working electrode and is connected in series with the counter electrode (e.g., Pt foil, Li foil) [81,82]. This approach can be performed at room temperature without involving hazardous fluoride-containing etchant, which is beneficial for industrial production. The etching mechanism of this approach involves the oxidation of “A” element from MAX phases, followed by the recovery of “A” metal ions at counter electrode via reduction process. With regards to the mentioned mechanism, the formation of electrochemically etched MXene is principally governed by the etching time, as well as the potential window and concentration of electrolyte [83]. Increase in electrical potential facilitates the breaking of MA bonds, thereby accelerates the removal of “A” layers from the MAX phases, and reduce the etching time required. In terms of electrolyte concentration, increase amount of etchant favours high etching rate owing to more aggressive material removal environment. However, aggressive synthesis parameters stimulate the formation of carbide-derived carbon (CDC) layers on the surface of the MAX phase precursor, ceasing the yield of MXene [63,84]. For instance, the viability of MXene production through electrochemical etching rely on the bond strength and selectivity of element removal in MAX phases, where the weaker MA bonds are prone to break before stronger MX bonds. Increasing the electrical potential, etching time, and electrolyte concentration allows the “M” elements to be etched as well, thereby forming CDC. Reducing the magnitude of the mentioned parameters diminishes the chance of yielding CDC but unavoidably leads to incomplete etching process and low synthesis yield. Further exploration on the optimal parameter combination is required to maximize the production rate while maintaining high purity of the yielded MXene. With the known fact that CDC is usually produced under a relatively harsh condition, a milder etching condition coupled with alternative electrolytes can be employed. It has been reported that the electrochemical system uses binary aqueous electrolyte consisting of 1 M NH4Cl and 0.2 M TMAOH can effectively produce MXene from MAX phases, with high synthesis yield greater than 90% [85]. The introduction of TMAOH can effectively increase the interlayer spacing of MAX phases precursor, allowing greater accessibility of Cl− to the “A” layer. In the case of Ti3AlC2, this has facilitated the etching of internal MAX phases by breaking more Ti-Al bonds [86,87]. Owing to the absence of fluoride-containing etchant throughout the process, the electrochemically etched MXene has abundant oxygen and hydroxyl terminations, corresponding to high pseudocapacitive performance [88]. In summary, the present state of emerging approaches demonstrates favorable scalability and established application. Despite their potential, these methods encounter substantial obstacles, including the elevated temperatures, limited MXene variants synthesized, and the generation of waste materials. Therefore, a comprehensive understanding of the underlying mechanisms and parameter optimization is essential to maximize the versatility of these methods. Additionally, it is evident that addressing these challenges also requires a call for innovative solutions. 3.3 Innovative approaches The intrinsic and coveted properties of MXene led to tremendous efforts in scaling up the production of MXene while minimizing the usage of hazardous etchant, decreasing etching temperatures, and reducing the waste production. Several novel synthesis routes that capable of solving the mentioned issues in conventional and emerging methods were reported in recent years, namely, thermal reduction etching, algae etching, ionic liquid etching, and wave-assisted etching, as summarized in Fig. 4 . Despite that the as-mentioned innovative methods are not primarily designed for supercapacitor application, it is noteworthy that these methods can produce MXene with similar morphology as that from conventional and emerging etching techniques, favorable for the production of MXene-based supercapacitor electrodes. Different from alkali and molten salt etching that requires large amount of etchant, the thermal reduction etching is solely a temperature dependent approach that capable to transform MAX phases to MXene with the assistance of H2 under inert condition. This eliminates the generation of hazardous acid, and alkali waste throughout the etching process. Aside from the minimized pollutant, this method is by far the first approach to transform sulfur-containing MAX phases into MXenes. The conventional HF etching will only yield carbon/sulfur amorphous, rather than MXene due to the inertness of sulfur [89]. The etching mechanism of thermal reduction is removing the weakly-bonded sulfur from MAX phases in the form of volatile hydrogen sulfide (H2S) after reacting with H2 under elevated temperatures. For instance, the multilayer Ti2C MXene can be obtained by removing the sulfur species in Ti2SC MAX phase at 800 °C [90]. Moreover, the loosely stacked multilayer MXene obtained after thermal reduction etching can be simply delaminated through ultrasonication without the presence of intercalant. This approach demonstrates a versatile solution in MXene synthesis without the need for hazardous wet chemical etching. It is crucial to consider the environmentally friendliness and safety while venturing from lab-to-commercial production. With the fact that most of the conventional and emerging MXene synthesis still involves acidic or alkali etchant, there is necessity to call for a hazardous-free method for MXene production. Replacing chemical reagent with bioderived organic acids extracted from microorganism in MXene synthesis appears to be one of the best solutions to mitigate the implementation of acidic and alkali etchants. The self-sustaining algae has been integrated into various green synthesis protocol for nanomaterials [91,92]. In terms of MXene synthesis, algae-assisted etching is reported to yield up to 90% vanadium carbide, V2C from V2AlC. The organic acids extracted from algae can efficiently intercalate, attack the amphoteric Al, and delaminate the V2AlC MAX phase [93]. The discovery of biochemical-based etching provides an alternative to the synthesis of underexplored vanadium and molybdenum-based MXene. In addition, the algae etching technique can be utilized to bulk produce MXene in a cost-effective manner owing to the ease in algae cultivation. Another innovative etching approach utilizes ionic liquid–water mixture as the etchant to produce carbide-based MXene. The mechanism of ionic liquid etching is extremely similar to that of the in-situ HF etching, where the etchant not only facilitates in the selective removal of “A” elements, but also served as an intercalant, enabling the delamination of multilayer nanosheets through mechanical exfoliation. For instance, the Ti3AlC2 and Ti2AlC MAX phases can be etched via hydrolysis by fluoride-containing ionic liquid (e.g., 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium hexafluoro-phosphate, and 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate), that leads to the selective removal of Al [94]. The fluorine in ionic liquid does not dissociate into fluoride ion, but present in the form of organic anion such as BF4 − and PF6 −, leading to minimal amount of fluoride termination on the yielded MXene. The additional merit of ionic liquid etching is its facile post-treatment compared to conventional acid etching. The pH of MXene-ionic liquid mixture is close to neutral range, allowing rapid isolation of the as-synthesized MXene. In addition, ionic liquid etching can fully retain oxide by-products in the ionic liquid–water mixture. The absence of oxide by-products can mitigate the oxidation of MXene and allow long-duration storage. However, the minimum period for complete reaction between ionic liquid and MAX phases is 20 h, a negligible reduction compared to the conventional acidic etching. The use of milder etchant has led to slower reaction rate, and thereby, highlight the necessity of applying external energy to accelerate the production rate. An alternative solution to the low reaction rate can be wave-assisted etching that provides additional energy, enabling a more efficient chemical reaction between etchant and MAX phases. For example, the electromagnetic and mechanical wave-assisted etching has been reported as a timely and milder approach to etch layered MAX precursors. Molybdenum-based MXene, Mo2C, can be produced from Mo2Ga2C with the aid of UV-light in a milder phosphoric acid (H3PO4) within 3 to 5 h. This technique enables high-yield production of fluoride-free mesoporous MXene, which is conducive for efficient electrolyte diffusion and charge transfer, highly-preferred for supercapacitor application [95]. In terms of mechanical wave-assisted etching, the Ti3C2 MXene can be produced rapidly in 0.05 M LiF under the exposure of surface acoustic waves [96]. The surface acoustic waves induce the dissociation of pure water to produce proton, followed by the in-situ formation of HF from the reaction of LiF and proton. The etching and delamination mechanism is similar to that of the in-situ HF etching with the only difference of the increased etching rate of Al from MAX phases owing to the incorporation of highly localized mechanical vibration, shortening the production period from the typical full day synthesis to 40 min. In addition to the accelerated etching kinetics, the aforementioned wave-assisted etching method eliminates the need for the neutralization process of the etchant-product mixture, which typically generates a significant amount of waste. This is achieved because neither acidic nor alkaline reagents are involved in the etching and delamination process. Specifically, the pH reduction caused by the in-situ HF formation returns to the neutral range once the wave is halted. These advantages collectively enhance the commercial potential of wave-assisted MXene synthesis, stemming from negligible waste generation and exceptional efficiency. These innovative approaches open up the opportunity for the synthesis of new MXene species that is only theoretically feasible at the moment. Meanwhile, these innovative techniques can be facilely incorporated with the existing synthesis methods as auxiliary mechanisms to synergistically increase the yield and production rate of MXene. Particularly, the wave-assisted etching technique can be integrated into in-situ HF etching method to accelerate the removal process of A layer in MAX phase precursors. 4 Fundamental design of 2D MXene As discussed above, the charge storage nature of MXene is fairly complex and concomitantly contributed by EDLC, intercalation, and surface redox pseudocapacitive mechanisms, ascribed to its diverse, rich surface chemistry and inherent nanostructure [21,32,33,66,97]. Considering that, the physical characteristics and surface functionalities of 2D MXene nanosheets are highly sensitive to the reactant composition and synthesis conditions. 2D MXene nanosheets are elementary building blocks for constructing 3D MXene architectures. Thus, the synthesis of 2D multi-layered or single-layered MXene determines the quality of the final 3D MXene architectures. The etching parameters that govern the quality of synthesized MXene include the particle size of the MAX phase or non-MAX phase precursors, etching period, etching temperature, and etchants used (nature of etchant and concentration). The combined effects of different parameters result in MXene with varying structural properties such as layer thickness, lateral size, number of defects, and composition of surface termination groups. Ultimately, these properties can be measured electrochemically to evaluate the specific capacitance, power density, energy density, and cyclic stability. 4.1 MAX phase precursors The forming materials, stoichiometry compositions, and valence states of MAX phase precursors have determining effects on the electrochemical properties of the resulting MXene. One way to categorize MXenes is based on the transition metals present in their structure which is solely governed by the elemental composition of their respective MAX phase precursors. Firstly, there are single transition metal or mono-metallic MXenes, such as the typical Ti3C2Tx with ordered MX layered structure synthesized from Ti3AlC2 [57]. Besides, the double transition metal or bi-metallic MXenes, which involve two different transition metals such as ordered Mo4VC4 with consistent layered pattern derived from Mo4VAlC4 [98], and solid solution-type TiVCTx with randomly distributed “Ti” and “V” in “M” layer derived from TiVAlC MAX phase [99]. Furthermore, MXenes can also be defined based on the presence of vacancies in their atomic structure. For example, the divacancy transition metal MXene contains two ordered “M” vacancy sites resulting from the selective removal of two distinct “A” elements [100]. Additionally, MXenes can be further classified into out-of-plane and in-plane structures based on the configuration of elements. In out-of-plane MXene, each of the “M” and “A” elements occupies entire layers in an alternating pattern, as seen in Ti3C2Tx with three “Ti” layers sandwiching two “C” layers [101]. In contrast, in in-plane MXene, the “M” and “A” elements are arranged in a hexagonal lattice pattern, as observed in the case of W1.33C Tx [102]. Moreover, MXene can also be classified into carbide-based, nitride-based, or carbonitride-based depending on the “X” counterpart present in the MAX phase precursor [103]. MXene inherits its properties from its parent precursor. MAX phase precursors produced from different carbon sources can result in carbide-based MXenes with non-identical flake sizes and morphologies. The graphite and TiC-synthesized Ti3AlC2 produce larger MXene flakes with high electrical conductivity up to 4400 and 3480 S cm−1 respectively [104]. The remarkable electrical conductivity is contributed by the high nucleation energy of the carbons used, thereby leading to few nucleation sites and resulting in larger crystal sizes with layered morphology (Fig. 5 a and b). On the contrary, the carbon lampblack has significantly lower nucleation energy, resulting in abundant nucleation sites and inevitably leading to smaller MXene crystals without a layered structure (Fig. 5c). The carbon lampblack-derived MXene has a relatively lower electrical conductivity of 1020 S cm−1. Moreover, the lack of layered configuration leads to easy restacking of MXene that essentially inhibits the intercalation of ions and utilization of redox-active sites, thereby hindering the charge transfer process for efficient energy storage. Besides the mono-transition-metal MXenes, a distinct subset within the MXene family can be synthesized by modifying the elemental composition of the MAX phase. The incorporation of two transition metal elements within the MAX phase structure can produce double-transition-metals MXenes, commonly referred to as bi-metallic MXenes ((M’M’’) n +1X n Tx). The synthesis of bi-metallic MXenes can be achieved through the conventional direct HF or in-situ HF etching of bi-metallic MAX phases [105,106]. In terms of their physical properties, bi-metallic MXenes exhibit significantly larger interlayer spacing when compared to their mono-transition metal MXene counterparts [107]. This expanded interlayer spacing promotes the diffusion and transportation of ions within the electrolyte system. For instance, the bi-metallic MXene Mo2Ti2C3, synthesized from the Mo2Ti2AlC3 MAX phase, boasts an interlayer spacing of 2.4 nm. This is 127% larger than the mono-transition-metal Ti3C2 MXene synthesized under the same conditions [108]. As a result, the Mo2Ti2C3 demonstrates a substantially higher specific capacitance of 152 F g−1, compared to the Ti3C2 electrode with 61 F g−1, at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 in a 1 M solution of 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl)-imide (EMIMTFSI) electrolyte. This improvement can be attributed to the reversible and more efficient intercalation of EMIM+ ions between the layers of the Mo2Ti2C3, whereas the lower specific capacitance of Ti3C2 may be attributed to the insufficient intercalation of EMIM+ ions, which primarily adhere to the outer surface and cannot diffuse into the interlayer. The high pseudocapacitive current contribution of Mo2Ti2C3 in comparison to Ti3C2 is primarily due to intercalation pseudocapacitance. The larger interlayer spacing facilitates the free and reversible intercalation/deintercalation of both bare and solvated EMIM+ and TFSI− ions. This is supported by the higher percentage of surface-controlled capacitance in Mo2Ti2C3, reaching 91%, in contrast to Ti3C2 with a lesser surface-controlled capacitance of 63% at a scan rate of 200 mV s−1. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy further underscores the significance of larger interlayer spacing. The charge transfer resistance of Mo2Ti2C3 is 3.4 Ω, considerably smaller than the value of 8.7 Ω for Ti3C2. This reduction in charge transfer resistance for Mo2Ti2C3 is attributed to its larger d-spacing, which facilitates the faster intercalation/deintercalation of bulky EMIM+ and TFSI− ions between the layers. In terms of cyclic stability, Mo2Ti2C3 demonstrates a higher capacitance retention of 86%, while Ti3C2 exhibits a lower retention rate of 64% after 5,000 charge/discharge cycles at a current density of 200 mA cm−2. A similar performance trend is evident with (Ti0.5V0.5)3C3Tx. In this case, the charge transfer resistance of the bi-metallic (Ti0.5V0.5)3C3Tx MXene is limited to 0.2 Ω, approximately two times lower than that of Ti3C2Tx MXene, and five times lower when compared to V2CTx MXene [109]. In terms of reliability as a supercapacitor electrode, (Ti0.5V0.5)3C3Tx MXene exhibits minimal degradation even after 100,000 cycles of continuous charge/discharge at a current density of 20 A/g. In contrast, the cyclic stability of V2CTx MXene decreases to 81% after only 10,000 charge/discharge cycles. The electrochemically stable bi-metallic (Ti0.5V0.5)3C3Tx MXene also demonstrates a surface-dominant charge storage mechanism, with a capacitance control ratio of 52% even at a low scan rate of 5 mV s−1. This indicates a surface-controlled charge storage. Conversely, Ti3C2Tx and V2CTx MXenes exhibit a relatively diffusion-controlled charge storage, with capacitance ratios of nearly 32% and 16% at the same scan rate. The surface-controlled charge storage suggests a larger interlayer spacing in (Ti0.5V0.5)3C3Tx MXene, enabling seamless ion transfer. Ultimately, this efficient ion transfer accounts for the outstanding charge storage capability and cyclic stability performance of (Ti0.5V0.5)3C3Tx MXene. Crucially, the bi-metallic MXenes discussed here do not involve the introduction of spacers or undergo structural modifications to form a 3D assembly. Therefore, the improved charge storage behaviour is solely attributed by the inherent stability of the layered structure and the naturally occurring larger interlayer spacing in these bi-metallic MXenes. On top of the selection of MAX phases with different transition metal counterpart, the choice of raw material for “A” elements has definite impact on the purity and structural integrity of the yielded MXene. The finding suggests that the vacancy-ordered Mo1.33CTx MXene synthesized from AlY2.3 alloy-derived (Mo2/3Y1/3)2AlC i-MAX has six-fold higher yield compared to the Mo1.33CTx synthesized from elemental Y-derived (Mo3/2Y1/3)2AlC i-MAX [100]. The latter MAX phases synthesis protocol has suppressed Mo1.33CTx MXene yield due to the higher tendency to form byproduct, namely Mo3Al2C. On top of the enhanced yield, the MXene synthesized from AlY2.3 alloy-derived (Mo2/3Y1/3)2AlC i-MAX has larger interlayer spacing, allowing efficient proton diffusion and increased charge storage site. Ultimately, the synthesized MXene exhibits higher charge storage capability with significantly higher specific volumetric capacitance at low scan rate compared to the MXene produced from Y-derived (Mo3/2Y1/3)2AlC i-MAX, providing that both of the MXene are technically “Mo1.33CTx”. Aside from the purity of MAX phases, the quantity of “A” elements used in the preparation of these phases significantly influences the physical properties of the synthesized MXene. Taking Ti3AlC2 as the example, increasing the amount of Al beyond the stoichiometry ratio of 3:1:2 promotes the diffusion of Al. This diffusion process leads to the development of Ti3AlC2 grains with enhanced structural integrity, thereby facilitating the creation of Ti3C2 with an optimal 3:2 ratio of Ti to C. Recent research indicates that MXene derived from the aforementioned MAX phases exhibits improved oxidation stability due to fewer defects in the carbon sublattice [9]. The highly stoichiometric MAX phases contribute to the resulting MXene with remarkable electronic conductivity up to 20,000 S cm−1, along with a prolonged shelf life exceeding 10 months, demonstrating minimal degradation over time. This synthesis protocol can be potentially applied to the synthesis of various MAX phases for high quality MXene. However, excess material indicates additional cost to the overall production cycle, and it is crucial to consider the cost efficiency beyond performance. Hence, integrating recycled materials into the synthesis of MAX phases offers a viable alternative for advancing the commercialization of MXene production. It has been reported that MAX phases derived from the utilization of inexpensive (i.e., TiO2) and recycled (i.e., secondary aluminum, and tire-derived carbon) materials can produce Ti3C2Tx MXene with a specific capacitance of 285 F g−1 (1,012 F cm−3) at 20 mV s−1, and electrical conductivity of 5857 ± 680 S cm−1 [53]. The electrochemical results are comparable to MXene synthesized from laboratory grade materials-derived MAX phases, yet with higher cost efficiency as no elemental precursors were used. These studies conclude that the foundation of achieving high-quality MXene lies in ensuring the production of high-quality MAX phases. MAX phases serve as the precursors from which MXene are derived, and their characteristics have a profound influence on the properties of the resulting MXene. Therefore, refining the properties of MAX phases is pivotal to unveil the full potential of MXene in supercapacitor application. 4.2 Synthesis conditions Being a kinetically controlled process, a strong relationship exists between etching temperature, etching duration, and properties of the as-synthesized MXene. The structural properties (particle size, number of defects, and surface termination groups) and electrochemical properties (capacitance and conductivity) of MXene are varied under different reaction conditions. The effects of etching temperature and ball milling on the etching process and the ensuing capacitance of Ti3C2Tx MXene using a 40 wt% HF solution were studied [110]. The research showed that pristine Ti3C2Tx MXene can be obtained after 48 h under the etching temperature of 35 °C and further reduced to 24 h under the etching temperature of 60 °C. XRD analysis revealed that the Ti3AlC2 MAX phase precursor was not fully etched to form Ti3C2Tx MXene at low etching temperature despite undergoing a longer etching period. The XRD patterns of samples (Fig. 5d-f) indicate that low etching temperature is ineffective in facilitating the complete elimination of Al layers from Ti3AlC2 MAX phase precursor. The assistance of ball milling in treating the precursor halved the etching time within the tested temperature range. The incorporation of ball milling produces MAX phase precursor with uniform and finer particle size, as well as enhance the overall surface-to-volume ratio by breaking the Van Der Waals interaction between the MAX phase layers. This pre-etching process ensures larger fraction of MAX phase precursor actively interact with the etchant to facilitate the selective removal of “A” element from the layered structure. In addition, ball milling has improved the specific capacitance and capacitance retention of etched Ti3C2Tx MXene by 37.5% and 6% respectively. This concludes that Ti3C2Tx MXene can be synthesized in a shorter time under a relatively higher etching temperature. Ball milling is also thus proven to be able to enhance the capacitance while reducing the etching time without disrupting the crystalline phase. Besides, the concentration of etchants also plays a crucial role in determining the etching protocols and quality of the etched MXene. In general, most of the reported HF-etching of Al from Ti3AlC2 MAX phase precursor uses 10 to 50 wt% HF. The concentration of HF decides the etching duration required for the transformation from precursor to MXene. A higher concentration (i.e., 10 wt%, 30 wt%, 40 wt%, and 50 wt%) is usually suggested to extract the “A” element from the MAX phase precursor [111]. Nevertheless, using lower HF concentration (i.e., 5 wt% for 24 h) has been proven to produce similar results as in the case of higher concentration [112,113]. However, Ti3C2Tx MXene obtained using diluted 5 wt% HF solution exhibits accordion-like morphology but with thicker lamellas, which is unfavorable for delamination process [114]. In addition, it was also reported to consist of fewer -F surface terminations that reduces the steric hindrance on the mobility of excess H2O molecules in the interlayers. The mobilized H2O molecules increase the interlayer spacing, allowing excess ions to reach the active sites [115]. Unfortunately, the utilization of diluted HF etchant will increase etching time, leading to structural instability and increase in sheet resistivity with a larger formation of AlF3 [116]. Nonetheless, the etching time also depends on the strength of the metallic M−A bonding in the MAX phase. Typically, precursors with greater metallic bonding between the transition metals, “M” and “A” species, require harsher etching conditions. For example, the etching of Nb2AlC requires 90 h, 45 times longer than that required for Ti3AlC2, which only requires 2 h with 50 wt% HF at 25 °C [117]. The longer etching duration is caused by a stronger Nb-Al bond compared to Ti-Al bond. As a remedy, the etching temperature is increased to 55 °C to reduce the etching time under the same etchant concentration. The combined effect of etching temperature, etching duration, and etchant concentration can significantly alter the synthesized MXene. Two different HF etching protocols were reported to prepare molybdenum-based MXene (Fig. 5j). The first approach is etching Al from (Mo2/3Y1/3)2AlC i-MAX in 48 wt% concentrated HF in a ratio of 1 g of (Mo2/3Y1/3)2AlC to 20 mL of etchant at room temperature and stirred for 12 h. This protocol yields (Mo2/3Y1/3)2C MXene with in-plane elemental order that can reach a volumetric capacitance of 1,550 F cm−3 in 6 M KOH electrolyte. In the second protocol, both Al and Y elements were etched from (Mo2/3Y1/3)2AlC i-MAX in 10 wt% HF solution in a ratio of 1 g of (Mo2/3Y1/3)2AlC to 20 mL of etchant at room temperature and stirred for 72 h with fresh 10 wt% HF substituted at every 24 h. This protocol yields Mo4/3C MXene with ordered vacancies, and the as-synthesized Mo4/3C MXene attained a volumetric capacitance of 1,200 F cm−3 in 1 M KOH electrolyte [118]. Aside from controlling the types of MXene yielded through various combination of etching parameters, it is noteworthy that different combination of etching temperature, etching duration, and etchant concentration will also affect the structural stability and charge transfer capability of the etched MXene. As Ti3C2Tx MXene is prone to oxidation when preparing in aqueous etchant with dissolved oxygen, the high etching temperature and duration will accelerate the formation of TiO2 which will cease the overall electrical conductivity of MXene owing to its dielectric nature. It has been reported that MXene synthesized at 80 °C can reach high oxygen content up to 29 wt% even it is etched in milder HCl/LiF etchant [119]. Meanwhile, the mentioned MXene has significant defect as evident from high intensity D band in Raman spectra which can be attributed to high temperature etching. On the contrary, the MXene synthesized below 50 °C yields relatively lower oxygen content and displays higher electrical conductivity with minimal defects. In the context of charge storage capability, the MXene synthesized at 80 °C has a specific capacitance of 396 F g−1 at 5 mV s−1 which is nearly half of the value compared to the MXene synthesized at 50 °C. In terms of cyclic stability, the MXene synthesized at 80 °C achieve a capacitance retention of 88% after 3,000 charge/discharge cycles at 1,000 mV s−1, slightly lower compared to the 50 °C sample with capacitance retention of 94%. The reduced specific capacitance and cyclic performance for MXene synthesized at 80 °C can be attributed to the excessive oxide layer that prevents the double layer formation on the MXene surface and also defect-rich surface that reduce the redox active sites. In addition, the oxidized MXene prevents efficient ion diffusion near the MXene surface which leads to a relatively higher charge transfer resistance. These reported findings suggest the auspicious potential of tailoring desirable properties for efficacious fabrication of MXene supercapacitors by fine tuning the synthesis parameters. In essence, moderate etching temperature alongside suitable etchant concentration is pivotal in ensuring high yield of high-quality MXene. Higher etching temperatures accelerate the transformation of MAX phases into multi-layered MXene. However, this could trigger surface oxidation that forms undesired TiO2 by-products and suppresses its overall electrical conductivity. On the contrary, low etching temperature reduces the etching rate owing to decreased etchant reactivity, leading to incomplete etching. Similarly, low etchant concentration provides less amount of active intercalant that can be reacted with “A” elements, thus retarding the etching process and yielding MXene with low purity. Consequently, the average synthesis time of MXene is bounded to hour-day scale due to inevitable trade-off between etching rate and product quality that is yet to be mitigated. Taking that into account, other means of reaction intensifying techniques such as microwave and ultrasound assistance can be integrated to complement the synthesis process instead. This can possibly accelerate the etching process without harshening it, preserving the MXene nanosheets from degradation. 5 Revolutionary architecturing of 3D MXene It is important to acknowledge that the electrochemical charge storage capability of an electrode is mainly governed by both charge and ion transport kinetics. Charge transport kinetic is derived from the nature of redox reactions occurring on the electrode surface and their reactivity, characterized by MXene chemical compositions, as well as the behavior of electron migration within the active material, dependent on its electronic states. All of which can be tuned via synthesis design, as discussed above. On the other hand, ion transport kinetic is used to describe to extend of electrolyte ion migration resistance and distance during charging/discharging operations. To tackle this, the pliability of MXene nanosheets allows the design of intricate and effective 3D MXene architectures. The porous 3D interconnected network of MXene retains the intrinsic properties of the 2D MXene nanosheets while realizing higher surface utilization by inhibiting restacking [120,121]. The assembly approaches define the electrochemical properties, including specific capacitance, rate capability, and cyclic stability by tuning the crucial parameters. This includes interlayer spacing, structural tortuosity and pore size control, all of which govern the ion transfer kinetic. Moreover, the chemical and physical stability of these 3D architectures upon repeated charging/discharging cycles is a crucial aspect to be considered as gradual degradation of these structures generally translates to poor cyclic stability. The performances of the different 3D MXene architectures are summarized in Table S2 in the supplementary materials. 5.1 Unidimensional architecturing As studies on exploring novel 3D MXene architectures become widely prevalent recently, the vast amounts of methods reported can be categorizable based on the complexity progression of the structural design. Unidimensional architecturing methods are classified as the strategies involving a single structural formation process that results in 3D architectures with features of similar dimensions. To date, such MXene frameworks are mainly achieved through self-assembly and templating methods. Multidimensional architecturing methods include strategies involving a secondary structural formation process that achieves sequential patterning of features of distinct dimensions, observing a hierarchical effect on the fabricated 3D architectures. This approach describes an array of studies that incorporated templating methods into additive manufacturing technologies, yielding structures with higher levels of intricacy. 5.1.1 Self-assembly The formation of 3D MXene architectures can be facilely accomplished by electrostatic self-assembly technique, wherein 2D MXene building blocks undergo spontaneous gelation with multiple nanomaterials into cross-linked 3D porous structures such as hydrogel or aerogel. In this technique, reductant is needed to initiate gelation process between separate MXene nanosheets via crosslinking of oxygen dangling bonds into an ensemble microstructure, typically with the assistance of a crosslinking agent [122]. Crosslinker also provides abundant functional groups, which can be grafted onto the nanosheets, granting them improved electrochemical reactivity. The assembly of 3D MXene is self-driven through van der Waals attraction between the MXene nanosheets alongside π-π interaction of crosslinker with MXene [123,124]. MXene hydrogel obtained from the crosslinking of nanosheets aided by graphene oxide (GO) and ethylenediamine has abundant macropores and low tortuosity contributed by the elimination of self-restacking and agglomeration of MXene nanosheets (Fig. 6 a) [125]. The as-fabricated supercapacitor delivered 50% higher specific capacitance compared to 2D MXene film, up to 370 F g−1 at 5 A g−1, and remarkable rate capability at ultrahigh scan rate. The enhanced specific capacitance is ascribed to the interconnected channel in self-assembled MXene hydrogel that allows unimpeded ion transfer. Other than ethylenediamine, NH2 and –SH groups on L-cysteine can be used to react with the OH group on MXene and GO to construct a cross-linked hydrogel macrostructure [4]. The assembled 3D macroporous structure offers the increase of lattice spacing and elimination of MXene nanosheets self-restacking, which results in abundant electrochemical active sites. In addition, the staggered channels provide shorter omnidirectional ions transport pathways, thereby facilitating excellent rate capability up to 52.0% under a 1500-fold scan rate increase. In terms of the charge storage mechanism, the 3D macroscopic structure demonstrates capacitive behavior, characterized by a steeper slope at lower frequency ranges in electrochemical impedance spectroscopy. Furthermore, the smooth ion transfer within the macroporous channel is quantitatively evident through power-law calculation with a 'b' value approaching 1, signifying ideal capacitive-controlled charge storage. This low ion transfer resistance environment ultimately mitigates internal resistance fluctuations during charge/discharge cycles. As a result, the 3D MXene electrode maintains more than 98% of its initial capacitance even after undergoing 10,000 cycles of charge/discharge at a scan rate of 1,000 mV s−1. Another work reported the usage of a low-cost bio-derived reductant, lignosulfonate, to address the surface-to-surface restacking issue for MXene by functionalizing the crosslinker and forming a 3D hydrogel under π–π interaction [126]. The self-assembled composite electrode exhibits a noticeable leftward shift from 6.98° to 6.05° in XRD, indicating an increased d-spacing from 1.26 to 1.47 nm. Besides, the interconnected porous structure creates accessible electrochemically active sites to electrolyte ions. As a result, the lignosulfonate-assembled MXene electrode exhibits nearly 200% higher specific capacitance up to 241F/g compared to 2D MXene electrode at a scan rate of 100 mV s−1. In the view of electrochemical impedance spectroscopy, the MXene composite electrode demonstrates nearly vertical impedance in low frequency region, implying excellent capacitive behavior that contributed by efficient ion transfer in 3D porous structure. Collectively, the 3D architecture formed with the assistance of organic crosslinker is capable of retaining 96.3% of its initial capacitance with a coulombic efficiency of 97.4% after 10,000 cycles. On the other hand, cation-induced gelation of MXene nanosheets into porous crosslinked structures can also be conducted with the assistance of metal ions. The introduction of metal ions disrupts electrostatic repulsion between the MXene nanosheets by bonding with the OH groups anchored on the “M” layers and subsequently binding the MXene nanosheets into interconnected porous networks [127]. The formation of MXene hydrogel is preferably catalyzed by divalent metal ions (e.g., Fe2+, Co2+, and Ni2+), that offer sufficient hydration energy to initiate the gelation process. A recent work has shown that the construction of 3D MXene hydrogel relies on the assistance of Zn2+ ions to diminish the electrostatic repulsive forces between MXene nanosheets and serve as a linker to initiate the gelation of MXene and reduced GO [128]. The assembled hydrogel has higher utilization of electrochemically active sites and increased interlayer spacing which allows faster ion transport. As a result, the hydrogel exhibits predominantly surface-controlled capacitive behavior, which leads to excellent rate capability and high specific capacitance of 393 F g−1 at 2 mV s−1, much higher than recently reported 2D MXene electrodes [129,130]. However, the self-assembling of 3D porous MXene architecture is highly disordered and uncontrollable, leading to the formation of void spaces from the unutilized macroscale pores, ultimately decreasing the structural density and volumetric capacitance. To address that, it is recommended to minimize excess void spaces to attain MXene electrodes with dense and ordered interconnected structures that offer enhanced volumetric capacitance [131]. A porous and ordered cross-linked structure can be obtained through self-assembly of Ti3C2Tx nanosheets and chitosan via hydrogen bonding and electrostatic interaction (Fig. 6b) [132]. This Ti3C2Tx@chitosan architecture exhibits a high specific surface area of 194.5 m2 g−1, which is 12-fold greater than pure Ti3C2Tx film, implying that larger ion accessible active sites can be utilized. Moreover, uniformly interconnected porous structure shortens the ion diffusion pathways, thereby allowing faster ion transfer. As a result, the charge storage kinetics of Ti3C2Tx@chitosan electrode is principally governed by surface-controlled capacitive processes. This is evidently shown by the excellent rate capability it displays, enabling it to retain high specific capacitance even at ultrahigh scan rate [133]. Furthermore, the Ti3C2Tx@chitosan electrode demonstrates outstanding cyclic stability, retaining 95.8% of its initial capacitance over 10,000 charge/discharge cycles, even at a high scan rate of 100 mV s−1. This exceptional stability can be attributed to the 3D porous structure induced by chitosan, which effectively minimizes the volume expansion and contraction of the electrode during the charge/discharge cycle. As a result, this structural reinforcement prevents the breakdown of MXene nanosheets, ensuring a consistently stable energy storage performance. In another work, dense 3D MXene network with a tunable porous structure can also be achieved by dissembling 3D MXene hydrogel into microgels and reassembling it with individual MXene nanosheets (Fig. 6c) [134]. The enhanced mesopores proportion contributed by the introduction of microgels facilitates undisturbed ion diffusion kinetics, which is favorable for developing electrodes with high charge storage ability. Notably, the reassembled MXene film attains high specific capacitance up to 736 F cm−3 even under increasing scan rate up to 2,000 mV s−1. Besides, the Trasatti analysis deduces high proportion of surface-controlled capacitance up to 90.8% in microgel-reassembled MXene film, implying efficient utilization of the moderately porous nanostructure. The results underscore the critical role of achieving an optimal balance between porosity and density in achieving exceptional volumetric capacitance, coupled with outstanding rate performance. These studies mark the necessity to explore high-density MXene film with well-distributed mesopores that enhance the ion transfer through the electrode. On the whole, self-assembly is a facile and simple technique to convert 2D MXene nanosheets into 3D porous architectures. The specific capacitance is boosted remarkably from such dimensional evolution, attributed to the enlarged surface area, increased interlayer spacing, interconnected pores and increased amount of exposed active functional groups for alleviated surface-controlled capacitance. The distribution of surface functionalities on 2D MXene nanosheets serves a primary role in establishing the location of crosslinking sites and initiating the process. Thus, nanosheets which are decorated with high concentration of surface functionalities can promote rich interactions with the functional groups of the crosslinker, aiding the facile formation of dense yet highly interconnected porous structures without requiring highly complex assembly procedures. However, it should be noted that self-assembly process lacks the ability to offer high resolution modulation of the resulting porous structure due to the spontaneity and unpredictability of the process itself. Therefore, it results in highly disordered MXene architectures, which tend to perturb ion transport. There has been reported techniques to rapidly align the orientation of MXene nanosheets via electric field during the gelation process to provide higher orderliness of pore arrangement but it is still unable to tune the pore size effectively [135]. It has been widely established that the pore size of these architectures should be similar to that of electrolyte ions, inaccurate size matching will bring about overall capacitance deterioration [136]. Hence, template-assisted formation comes in place as an alternative to offer the perk of precise porosity modulation while building the 3D porous structure. 5.1.2 Templating methods Capitalizing on the mechanical flexibility of delaminated 2D MXene nanosheets, template-assisted assembly facilitates porous structure tuning of the resulting electrode by introducing a backbone scaffold. This is to assist the favorable alignment and directional layer-by-layer construction of MXene nanosheets, contouring the structure of the scaffold material. The scaffold or template material is then removed selectively, resulting in a hollow MXene structure with an intricate porous network (Fig. 7 c and d) that ameliorates ion transport process. Precise porosity modulation of 3D MXene structures is commonly performed by incorporating either ice or polymer template, due to their chemical inertness and versatile shape forming abilities. In fact, tuning the reaction conditions or including functional additives has been reported to be greatly efficacious in customizing the physical characteristics of these templates, leading to a myriad of distinct 3D MXene structures. The facile template designability of this approach allows higher control over the porous structure formation as compared to self-assembly. Hence, numerous research exploited this by probing the effects of various methodically designed 3D MXene structures on the electrode electrochemical properties. The ultimate goal is to collectively strive towards exhaustive optimization of ion transport kinetic, in order to realize high specific capacitance and rate performance simultaneously. Imparted by its abundant negatively charged surface terminations, the high aqueous stability of 2D MXene nanosheets allows the convenient in-situ formation of ice crystals among the nanosheet dispersion. This expands the dense, layered structure and minimizes interlayer Van der Waals interactions [137]. Low pressure sublimation of these ice crystals effectively obtains a highly uniform 3D MXene network formation. A simplistic method was developed where Ti3C2Tx aqueous suspensions were subjected to rapid freezing via immersion in liquid nitrogen, followed by freeze drying and annealing [138]. Two distinct MXene structures of 3D macroporous film and aerogel were obtained, displaying outstanding specific surface areas of 45.1 and 177.6 m2 g−1 respectively. At the low scan rate of 1 mV s−1, the 3D macroporous film achieved a gravimetric capacitance of 378 F g−1 in 3 M H2SO4, which is further increased to 414 F g−1 for MXene aerogel. Calculations showed that 59% and 63% of the capacitive performance were contributed by surface-controlled capacitance for 3D macroporous film and aerogel respectively. This can be logically deduced that the open network of generated macropores in the aerogel provided a more significant specific surface area enhancement, thereby expediting the access of electrolyte ions toward redox-active sites. Consequently, higher redox-active site utilization led to improved gravimetric capacitance, while the larger macropore network aided rapid ion diffusion for boosted surface-controlled capacitance. However, the 3D macroporous film was shown to exhibit a higher volumetric capacitance of 1,355 F cm−3 at 1 A g−1, compared to that of the aerogel at 1,293 F cm−3. Due to different freezing modes, the formation of large interconnected pores within the aerogel occupied higher volume without contributing electrochemical activity, diluting the volumetric capacitance performance. This shows that variation in ice template formations is able to tailor the electrode performance in different aspects, displaying great tunability for specific applications. Unfortunately, strong electrostatic repulsion of negatively charged MXene nanosheets resulted in their weak gelation ability [139–141]. Simple freeze drying of MXene suspension will only yield structures constituted of randomly aligned, sparsely connected nanosheets that impede rapid electron traveling. GO has been commonly used as a gelation agent, but its low conductivity and inferior specific capacitance may degrade the electrochemical performance of the resulting composite structure [125,140,142]. KOH was reportedly added into Ti3C2Tx suspension to weaken the nanosheets’ electronegativity by substituting –F with less electronegative –OH terminations [143]. This aided with the flocculation of colloidal Ti3C2Tx suspension into aggregates and the freeze-dried product obtained an ordered honeycomb-like structure, as shown in Fig. 7(a). Comparing their specific capacitances, the KOH-treated freeze-dried film achieved an enhanced value of 358.8 F g−1 at 20 mV s−1 compared to partially reduced GO as a gelation agent with a value of 218.1 F g−1. The strengthened interlayer bonding between Ti3C2Tx nanosheets suppresses charge transfer resistance, that is otherwise increased by poorly electrical conducting GO. The enhanced charge transfer kinetic alongside excellent ion transfer kinetic induced by the ordered 3D structure, led to the combination of higher specific capacitance and favorable rate performance, retaining 58.6% of its capacitance when increasing the scan rate from 10 to 10,000 mV s−1. Furthermore, 93.8% of its capacitance was retained after 10,000 CV cycles, owing to the strong ordered structure that maintained structural integrity even at high active material mass loading of 16.18 mg cm−2. High areal capacitance of 3.731F cm−2 obtained indicated its thickness-independent performance attributed to the exposure of deep redox-active sites by the construction of such 3D architecture. Aside from KOH treatment, CNT was used as a supporting material where the incorporation of CNT multifunctional spacers prior to freeze drying expands the interlaying spacing of Ti3C2Tx, allowing deeper penetration of water molecules into the internal structure [144]. Referring to Fig. 7(b), the higher amount of interlayer water accommodated during the freezing stage induced a more developed formation of ice crystal networks.
