Consequently, after the addition of CNT spacers, the specific capacitance evidently increased from 323.3 to 375 F g−1 at scan rate of 5 mV s−1, while the proportion of surface-controlled capacitance increased from 89.6% to 94.5%, owing to greater exposure of redox-active MXene nanosheets surfaces to electrolyte and unhindered ion transport respectively, both contributed by the highly open architecture. Beyond accelerating electron shuttling within the internal electrode microstructures by providing highly conductive pathways, the integrated CNT also improve the structural integrity and flexibility of the fabricated film, successfully obtaining a capacitance retention of 95.9% after 10,000 cycles. Aside from introducing electrochemically inactive materials to tune the porous structure, optimizing the freezing technique and parameters allow variations in the ice crystal growth, thereby altering the direction, shape, and size of the developed macropores. An interesting method was proposed to realize unidirectional freezing where ice crystals were allowed to grow in a single direction following a designed temperature gradient [145]. As a result, Ti3C2Tx nanosheets aligned accordingly such that vertical channels were formed orderly, as shown in Fig. 7(c–e). Subsequent thawing of the frozen structure using H2SO4 removes the ice crystals without destroying the integrity of the remaining microstructure. Among various works reporting the construction of 3D MXene architectures using ice templates, the present technique features a structure with the lowest tortuosity, which is the dominating factor determining its ion transfer kinetic. The ordered Ti3C2Tx hydrogel exhibited excellent specific capacitance of 393.0F/g at 5 mV s−1 and was able to retain 50.3% of it at 1,000 mV s−1. This is attributed to the vertical hollow channels acting as ion transport “highways”, providing unobstructed accessibility toward most redox-active sites even at high scan rates. Aside from maximizing ion transport efficiency, these channels with ultralow tortuosity minimizes structural alterations caused by the process of ions traversing in and out of the channels. Simultaneously, protons contributed by H2SO4 intercalate into the interlayer of Ti3C2Tx, which counteract Van der Waals attraction forces to hinder disassembly of the pre-assembled architecture. Synergistic preservation of the 3D architecture allows a capacitance retention of 95.5% after 10,000 cycles. When fabricated into a micro-supercapacitor (MSC), an areal capacitance of 2.0F cm−2 was achieved at 1.2 mA cm−2. It is suggested that this value can be potentially boosted by optimizing the diameter of the vertically constructed channels to minimize unnecessary void occupancy while maintaining minimal hindrance towards electrolyte ion transport. Another work proposed a dual-step freezing strategy to ensure intricate control over the formation kinetics of ice crystals [137]. The multistage process involved prior rapid freezing at −196 °C; this ultralow freezing temperature triggered a nucleate-dominant process that could initiate uniformly small ice crystallization within the dense interlayer of Ti3C2Tx nanosheets while inhibiting excessive growth of these crystals. This is followed by a second stage of slow rate freezing at −20 °C. The growth-dominant process ensuing from this freezing temperature allows the ice nuclei to grow into large anisotropic crystals, effectively disrupting the interlayer Van der Waals interactions. The elaborate design of ice template network allows the thorough seeding of ice crystals into deep MXene structures before expanding these enclosed layers, maximizing uniform formation between every layer, that is otherwise, unachievable through conventional single-step freeze drying. The comprehensive unravelling of dense internal structures resulted in the high specific capacitance of 398 F g−1 at 0.5 A g−1. However, the generation of highly concentrated, vast porous channels within the MXene structures inevitably degrades areal and volumetric capacitance, demanding further exploration of 3D architectures to address this dilemma. While utilizing an ice crystal template offers a straightforward and inexpensive approach to constructing desirable porous structures, the degree of designability is still relatively limited. On that account, polymer and metal-based spherical templates provide an intriguing alternative as their size and morphology can be directly altered based on their synthesis procedures. As such, a great deal of research has embedded a variety of nanoparticles synthesized from polystyrene (PS), poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA), iron (III) hydroxide (Fe(OH)3), and magnesium oxide (MgO) into 2D MXene nanosheet dispersion [45,70,146–152]. This is generally followed by vacuum filtration of the composite material, and further annealing ensures complete template removal; what remains is a MXene skeletal structure with well-defined macropores engraved by the respective template. Therefore, the tweaking of the physicochemical properties of the template material can be directly reflected in the distinct porous structure of the derived MXene films. A comprehensive method was presented to fabricate a high performance flexible MXene-based electrode on the basis of microscale structural engineering and surface chemistry modification [153]. Essentially, PMMA nanospheres were used as template spacers which intercalate into Ti3C2Tx interlayer to facilitate even in-situ polymerization of reactive polymer monomers on the layer surfaces. The combination of PMMA nanospheres and various grown polymers provides the interlayer expansion necessary for the following alkalization step. Alkali treatment with KOH replaces the redox-inactive -F terminations with OH terminations, while K+ ions further participate in the enlargement of interlayer spacing. Removal of PMMA nanospheres and carbonization of the in-situ grown polymer was then performed via calcination, where the OH terminations were also converted to redox-active O terminations. Polymer carbonization successfully grafts its functional groups onto Ti3C2Tx layers, supplying more electrochemically active sites for increased capacitance. Consequently, in-situ carbonization of different polymer types has conspicuously enhanced the capacitive behavior compared to pure Ti3C2Tx film, as shown in Fig. 8 (a). The magnitude of enhancements is dependent on the interlayer expansion and surface functional groups grafting imparted by the different polymers. Similarly, despite undergoing carbonization, the incorporation of different polymers displayed variation in ion transport kinetic of the resulting electrode, influenced by the inherent chemical structure of these polymers. Fig. 8(b) summarizes the varying surface-controlled capacitive proportion for the different carbonized polymers. Notably, the polythiophene-modified electrode (P-MXene/CPTh-A) suffers from exceedingly poor rate performance. This is due to carbonized polythiophene possessing the structure of agglomerated lumps and carrying bulky sulfone bridges, both causing massive hindrance towards ion transport in between MXene nanosheets. Tunability of the electrode capacitive and rate performance is derived from the scrutinization of polymer selected to be incorporated. Conceptually, it can be argued that incorporating large PMMA spherical templates leads to poor volumetric capacitance as the template sacrificial creates large “dead volumes” that does not contribute electrochemical activities. To address this, small Fe(OH)3 nanoparticles with a diameter of 3–5 nm were used to construct nanoscale porous channels within Ti3C2Tx layers [146]. As illustrated in Fig. 8(c), the positive charge of Fe(OH)3 nanoparticles and the negative charge of Ti3C2Tx nanosheets allow tight embedment of nanoparticles onto the layer surfaces via electrostatic attraction. Fig. 8(d and e) distinguish a typical Ti3C2Tx film and the nanoporous film; the generated nanochannels maximize interlayer connectivity and ion accessibility without significantly altering the typical layered structure. Minimal “dead volume” occupied by these nanochannels ensued a remarkable volumetric capacitance of 1,142 F cm−3 was reported, alongside a notable enhancement in the rate capability. The relaxation time constant, τ 0 of the optimized film electrode was calculated to be 1.96 s, experiencing approximately 90% reduction compared to pristine Ti3C2Tx film at 17.24 s, signifying accelerated ion transport. Nonetheless, this comparison was made relative to pure Ti3C2Tx film with restacked layers without any forms of structural modification. There is a possibility that the nanochannels facilitate inferior ion transport kinetic compared to other works that features larger spacious pore channels for suppressed ion transport hindrance. Furthermore, the porous structures discussed thus far have not deviated much from layered configuration; ion diffusion direction perpendicular to the plane of MXene layers is, therefore, only possible along the edges of the nanosheets. The need for electrolyte ions to navigate to the edges in order to traverse into the inner layers for complete surface utilization poses the problem of long diffusion pathways and is reflected in its sluggish ion transport. To target this issue, a recommended methodology is illustrated in Fig. 8(f) [152]. It combines the utilization of MgO nanoparticles as sacrificial templates to indent Ti3C2Tx nanosheets into curvy layers for preventing dense stacking. This was complemented with the intercalation and in-situ decomposition of urea on the curvy Ti3C2Tx nanosheets that create in-plane macropores. The in-plane macropores serve as shortcuts to accelerate the ion shuttling process between adjacent nanosheets. The combined integration of MgO nanoparticles and urea obtained curvy porous layers that ease bidirectional ion transport, parallel and perpendicular to the alignment plane of Ti3C2Tx nanosheets. Unfortunately, the generation of in-plane macropores does not come without a price. The introduction of in-plane surface point defects reduces the amount of surface redox-active sites for charge storage, decreasing its maximum capacitive capability. This may be reflected in mediocre areal and volumetric capacitance, which were not reported in this work. The surface point defects were also shown to act as nucleation sites that escalate localized oxidation into TiO2 crystals, eventually degrading the quality of MXene nanosheets [154,155]. Another approach is to match the template size to that of MXene nanosheets to ensure that the MXene nanosheets tightly contour the template circumference. Removal of the template leads to the remaining MXene structure closely retaining the 3D spherical morphology; this, in turn, completely eliminates the long ion diffusion pathway issue associated with the typical layered structure. An example of this macroporous structure was achieved by wholly wrapping PMMA microspheres with Ti3C2Tx nanosheets [147]. The open spherical morphology drastically shortened the ion diffusion pathways, revealing excellent rate performance. The fabricated macroporous film exhibited extremely low τ0 value of 316 ms, indicating a much more rapid ion transport than the nanoporous film discussed above. This is further supported by the 89% capacitive contribution by surface-controlled activity at the scan rate of 100 mV s−1. This proves that the establishment of “dead volume” minimized nanochannels intensifies its volumetric capacitance, but is plagued with heightened hinderance to the transfer rate of electrolyte ions. From this, it can be deduced that the template size is one of the determining factors that dictates the ion transport kinetic. Realizing the need for an in-depth study on this, the effect of the size difference between the templates and Ti3C2Tx nanosheets on the morphology of as-fabrication Ti3C2Tx foam was investigated [149]. By using PS nanospheres of varying diameters (80, 310, and 570 nm), shown in Fig. 9 (a–c), MXene foams with the corresponding varying cavity diameters were acquired, as shown in Fig. 9(d–f). Comparing the ion transport route for each structure, as shown in Fig. 9(g–i), the appropriate size matching between templates and nanosheets resulted in the shortest transport pathway. Too small a template size still causes the majority of nanosheets to stack layer-by-layer at certain regions, while too large a size squeezes the nanosheets to the free space in between the spherical templates, causing severe stacking at that area as well. The optimized template size also achieved the highest exposure of charge storage sites, resulting in highest utilization of active material, as evident in its highest gravimetric and volumetric capacitance of 474 F g−1 and 1,121 F cm−3 at scan rate of 2 mV s−1, respectively. The least tortuous ion transport pathways allow the highest capacitive retention of 115 F g−1 and 268 F cm−3 as well. Owing to the large pore volume present within these highly porous structures, a final mechanical compression can be performed on the macroporous film to reduce excess void spaces for enhanced areal and volumetric capacitance while retaining its high surface area nature. A high-performance positive electrode was realized by using PS nanospheres as templates and subsequent coating of PANI on the 3D architecture, as illustrated in Fig. 9(j) [45]. The 3D spherical morphology allows uniform surface coating of PANI, which simultaneously amplifies the specific capacitance and protects the Ti3C2Tx nanosheets underneath from oxidation at the anodic potential. After PS sphere removal via annealing, a compact film can be obtained by compressing the hollow porous structure. The electrochemical performance of the fabricated electrode is presented in Fig. 9(k). At a scan rate of 10 mV s−1, excellent gravimetric and volumetric capacitance of 510 F g−1 and 1,632 F cm−3 was achieved at 10 mV s−1, respectively. Its remarkable rate performance is demonstrated by its ability to operate at ultrahigh current density. As reported, a relatively high capacitance retention of 65.4% was observed when raising the current density from 1 to 1,000 A g−1. This is strongly correlated to the high contribution of surface-controlled capacitance at 10 mV s−1, occupying 84% of total capacitance, as depicted through the enclosed area label as “C-10 mV s−1” in the cyclic voltammogram. From this, it is shown that mechanical compression post processing has successfully condense the 3D architecture which improved volumetric capacitance, while also retaining sufficient ion transport macroporous channels to preserve rapid ion transfer kinetic, characterized by its remarkable rate performance. However, it is important to note that its reproducibility should also be considered. As different 3D architectures produced have distinct microstructures that vary from one another, slight local variations in the microstructures may cause amplified consequences on the compressed film. For example, 3D architectures containing locally dense structure may lead to total blockage of ion transport pathways at that area upon compression, ultimately resulting in detrimental rate performance deterioration. Upon critical discussion of a wide range of developed porous structures, it can be concluded that it is incredibly challenging to truly accomplish both high capacitance and high-rate performance concurrently. In fact, it is stressed that the electrode structure should be tailored to meet different performance requirements [70]. A fabricated typical densely packed, 2D layered Ti3C2Tx film attained outstanding volumetric performance of up to 1,500 F cm−3 but severely lagged behind in its rate performance. The opposite was observed for a macroporous Ti3C2Tx film fabricated using PMMA microspheres as sacrificial template. Taking a look at the ion transport resistance for both films, the resistance of macroporous film remained at 0.04 Ω cm2 for all scanning potentials which is multiple magnitudes lower than that of the layered film, associated with the minimization of ion transport distance. Evidently, it still remains a challenge to alleviate the obvious trade-off between the two determining electrode performance parameters [8]. This discovered trade-off can be used to describe the bottleneck faced by self-assembly and templating methods. Referring to Table S2, 3D architectures fabricated via self-assembly techniques generally offers superior rate performance, commonly reported to be able to operate at ultrahigh current densities of 1,000 A g−1, but suffers from poor areal/volumetric capacitance. On the contrary, templating method is able to yield electrodes exhibiting appealing areal and volumetric capacitive performance, often obtaining values beyond 3 F cm−2 and 1000 F cm−3 respectively, they however, lags behind in terms of rate performance. This raises the impending need to further increase the structural design freedom of porous MXene electrodes in order to simultaneously boost both performance parameters beyond the trade-off bounded limitations. Thus, rising research interest are directed towards using additive manufacturing to customize template material with extremely high resolution features [156]. 5.2 Multidimensional architecturing Constructing various 3D architectures via self-assembly and templating strategies have been proven to be widely efficacious in mitigating the restacking phenomenon of MXene, validated by exceptional enhancements of electrode specific surface area, gravimetric capacitance and rate performance. The improved gravimetric capacitance stems from the higher charge storage utilization of MXene nanosheets, essentially reducing “dead mass” that does not contribute electrochemically. Nevertheless, pores formed during the construction of these 3D architectures, regardless of the size, usually generates “dead volume” that brings adverse impacts to its areal or volumetric capacitance. This is undesirable to minimize footprint area and bulkiness in miniatured wearable electronic applications. The pore size draws the trade-off line between areal/volumetric capacitance and rate performance, such that small pore size causes the MXene nanosheets to be more densely packed, offering more charge storage sites per unit area or volume, but induces higher ion transfer resistance with its tortuous pathways. This is vice versa for larger pore size, as illustrated in Fig. 10 (a). In self-assembly techniques, 3D macrostructures are directly assembled by altering the alignment and orientation 2D MXene nanosheets, generally obtaining architectures with larger pore size. In contrast, MXene nanosheets are individually bent to offer microstructure fine tuning with smaller pore size in templating methods. Both approaches are positioned at both ends of the spectrum, where the complexity of structural engineering offered are restricted either by the chemical properties of crosslinking agents for self-assembly, or constraints inherent to mould-based fabrication for templating methods. Hence, there rises a need to look beyond unidimensional approaches and venture into multidimensional architecturing strategies to engineer microstructures onto macrostructures with high structural precision to construct “microstructured macrostructures”. The macrostructure serves as a base network with sufficiently large pore channels for bulk transportation of electrolyte ions while microstructures are built onto the base macrostructure to amplify the concentration of available charge storage sites. Such high precision engineering of miniscule structures is achievable with the inclusion of additive manufacturing technologies. Furthermore, this technological progression is in line with the current trend of fabricating thick electrodes in order to meet the demand for high-power devices [157–159]. Active materials in these electrodes are usually not completely utilized, in the sense that, electrolyte ions have to travel tremendously long pathways through the thick structures. It is often the case that the ions are unable to reach the inner layers, rendering them inactive materials, ultimately degrading its specific capacitance. Additive manufacturing provides the customizability to manually space out dense structures for effortless deep penetration of electrolyte ions, granting it superior thickness-independent capacitance. It is well known that optimizing the formulation of printing ink remains the primary pressing issue to be solved for extrusion-based 3D printing (EBP). MXene, possessing desirable properties intrinsically, presents as a compelling nanomaterial choice for the formulation of these inks. The hydrophilicity of MXene, attributed to its negatively-charged surface functional groups, allows facile dispersion in aqueous media. It has been commonly reported that these MXene inks can be directly employed, displaying shear-thinning properties favourable for its smooth and continuous extrudability, without additive requirements to regulate its rheological properties [164–166]. In fact, by varying the MXene concentration, the ink viscosity can be tuned accordingly [161]. However, additional requirements for a well-formulated ink include excellent electrical conductivity, strong thixotropic behaviour for rapid viscosity recovery at zero-shear state and appropriate viscoelastic characteristics for structural sustainability of 3D printed structures. Therefore, increasing amounts of studies are currently dedicated towards formulating MXene-based 3D printing inks with synergistic properties. A highly concentrated, additive-free, aqueous Ti3C2Tx dispersion was synthesized and utilized as printing ink for direct ink writing (DIW) [160]. Due to the fact that the printed electrodes were air-dried, the Ti3C2Tx nanosheets were deposited layer-by-layer and retained a dense layered structure with severe restacking upon drying, as displayed in Fig. 10(b). Although it was demonstrated that multiple layers can be printed on top of each other while maintaining structural integrity for the fabrication of thick electrodes, the increase in areal capacitance is not proportional to the number of printed layers. At 2 mV s−1, the fabricated MSC attained areal capacitances of 168.1, 315.8, 685.4 and 1,035 mF cm−2 with 1, 2, 5 and 10 printed layers respectively. It can be estimated that the areal capacitances only managed to achieve 93.9%, 81.5% and 61.6% of the ideal value achievable at 2, 5 and 10 layers respectively, assuming it increases proportionally with every layer deposited. Moreover, the rate capability of these electrodes decays with increasing number of printed layers, corroborated by the high τ 0 values of 5.5 s and 24.3 s for single and 10 printed layers respectively, drastically higher than that of the nanoporous and macroporous films discussed above. The MSC with 10 printed layers also exhibited substandard rate performance, with its areal capacitance dropping from 695 mF cm−2 at 10 mV s−1 to a mere 20 mF cm−2 at 1,000 mV s−1. This shows that, despite EBP being able to provide macrostructure designing, it inherently results in dense layered microstructure similar to that of pristine MXene without any auxiliary processing steps, inevitably leading to sluggish ion transfer kinetic. When increasing the number of printed layers, electrolyte ions have to traverse through longer tortuous pathways. Higher proportion of them are unable to reach deep charge storage sites, resulting in disparity between number of printed layers and the ensuing areal capacitance enhancement. Realizing the need to incorporate microstructures onto these macrostructures, an additional step of freeze drying was employed on the wet 3D architectures fabricated from EBP [161]. In this study, an aqueous ink was formulated using high aspect ratio Ti3C2TX nanosheets, this allows rheology tuning at low concentrations, reducing the probability of restacking. The 3D printed structures were freeze dried to rapidly remove water content within the microstructures while maintaining structural integrity of the remaining Ti3C2Tx nanosheets network, resulting in 3D microstructures. Fig. 10(c and d) provide an overview of the 3D printed macrostructure and the subsequent microstructure imprinted by freeze drying. The printed MSC was able to achieve an areal capacitance of 2.1 F cm−2 at 1.7 mA cm−2 and retained a value of 1.0 F cm−2 at 42.7 mA cm−2 (25-fold increase), indicating rate performance enhancement imparted by microstructuring, as compared to the previous work. To further modulate the pore formations of these microstructures, the technique of unidirectional freeze casting (UFC), similar to the one discussed above, was hybridized into a EBP study [162]. In this study, a printing ink comprising of Ti3C2Tx nanosheets, silver nanowires (AgNWs), manganese dioxide wires (MnONWs) and fullerene (C60) was formulated. The inclusion of AgNWs, MnONWs and C60 are to provide electrical conductivity enhancement, boost pseudocapacitance and serve as nanolubricant to minimize sliding friction between adjacent Ti3C2Tx nanosheets for structural flexibility, respectively. A temperature gradient was used to catalyze unidirectional growth of ice crystals, the resulting parallel orientation of Ti3C2Tx nanosheets constructed a honeycomb-like scaffold, as illustrated in Fig. 10(e). The highly dense formation of parallel macroporous channels enables unhindered ion transport in deep charge storage sites, leading to good rate performance, attaining areal capacitance of 216.2 mF cm−2 at 10 mV s−1 and maintaining a value of 72.8 mF cm−2 at high scan rate of 2,000 mV s−1. Furthermore, electrolyte can infiltrate the scaffold to fill up the macropore channels, indirectly preventing the collapse of the microstructures. Consequently, 85% retention of the initial capacitance was achieved after 10,000 charging/discharging cycles. Another study has raised the concern that, these vertical channels are constructed via anisotropic alignment of MXene sheets, ameliorating ion transfer process in the z direction [163]. Due to the fact that electrical conductivity is an anisotropic property as well, the microstructure exhibits good electrical conductivity in the z direction but lags behind in the x-y plane. As a solution, inkjet printing was used to fabricate a current collector, followed by air drying, resulting in horizontally aligned Ti3C2Tx nanosheets. Subsequently, a novel 3D freeze-printing (3DFP) was developed such that droplets of Ti3C2Tx nanosheet dispersion were instantly frozen on the substrate, the printed current collector in this case, following a temperature gradient. Upon freeze drying, the printed MSC consists of bidirectional orientation of Ti3C2Tx nanosheets. Horizontally aligned current collector limits charge transfer resistance in the x-y plane and the vertically aligned macroporous channels accelerate ion transfer process in the z direction, comprehensively enhancing its rate performance. Fig. 10(f) shows the printed macrostructure along with its corresponding aligned microstructure formations. It is also demonstrated that such formation of macroporous channels is advantageous towards achieving thickness-independent performance, where its gravimetric capacitance did not degrade when increasingly thick electrodes were printed. As discussed above, nitride-based MXenes present the advantage of higher electrical conductivity compared to carbide-based MXenes but its utilization is impeded by synthesis limitations. Nitrogen doping (N-doping) carbide-based MXenes presents as a convenient alternative. A study reported the usage of melamine formaldehyde (MF) nanospheres as sacrificial templates, where Ti3C2Tx nanosheets spontaneously encapsulates the nanospheres due to electrostatic interactions [167]. The removal of MF nanospheres via annealing resulted in crumpled N-doped Ti3C2Tx nanosheets. It was subsequently mixed with CNT, GO and activated carbon (AC) to formulate the printing ink for EBP. The presence of Ti-N bonds, validated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, indicated the successful substitution of carbon atoms with the rich nitrogen species contributed by MF. After EBP, the N-doped Ti3C2Tx nanosheets managed to retain their crumpled nature and established 3D microstructures within the printed macrostructures. As a result, the printed single-layer MSC demonstrated excellent areal capacitance of 3.4 F cm−2 at 10 mV s−1. However, it achieved a value of 5.2 F cm−2 with double printed layers, 76.5% of the ideal value achievable if the areal capacitance increases proportionally with printed layers. At three layers, it attained 8.2 F cm−2, 80.4% of the ideal value, which is not a downgraded performance compared to double-layers electrode. This signifies that the areal capacitance enhancement is only marginal at the second printed layer of the electrode. This is possibly due to the weight of the second layer applying stress on the bottom layer, compressing it onto the substrate beneath, causing the 3D microstructures to collapse. The macropores provided by the 3D microstructures in the bottom layer allow interstitial filling of the second layer, minimizing compression stress on the second layer when a third layer is deposited, this applies for any subsequent layers printed. The 3D architecture was proven to be relatively stable upon cycling, retaining 96.2% of the initial capacitance after 5,000 cycles. Majority of the studies incorporating EBP reported thus far, fabricated interdigitated macrostructures for its practical manufacturing of MSCs. The layer-on-layer deposition of EBP comes with the drawback of structural collapse of the bottom layer, this issue may exacerbate when large number of layers are printed to fabricate thick electrodes to meet the demand of high-power demand applications. It is imperative to explore truly 3D macrostructures embedded with overhang features to construct omnidirectional periodic structures. These pre-assembled macrostructures facilitate precise tuning of pore channel diameter and distribution while providing rigidity to limit strain caused by stress induced in all directions, comprehensively preserving ion transport pathways for rapid transfer processes. This allows intensification of areal/volumetric capacitance by building thick electrodes without compromising its rate performance. As it is extremely challenging to obtain such overhang features embedded-macrostructures via EBP, an interesting study incorporated digital light processing (DLP) 3D printing instead [156]. The higher printing resolution of DLP as compared to EBP allowed the printing of a 3D lattice resin template with tiny hollow struts, an aqueous Ti3C2Tx ink was then injected into the hollow struts, completely infusing the template internally. The impregnated template was immersed in NaOH solution to etch the template shell and catalyze the crosslinking of Ti3C2Tx nanosheets into hydrogel network. A final freeze-drying step yielded MXene aerogels with the combination of 3D macrostructures and microstructures, as shown in Fig. 10(g). Owing to the hampered tortuosity contributed by the macrostructure along with the maximization of electrode/electrolyte interface contributed by the microstructure, the 3D architecture electrode exhibited exceptional areal capacitance and rate performance. It managed to achieve 1.23 F cm−2 at 1 mA cm−2 with 83.7% retention at 100 mA cm−2. This is supported by the high capacitive contribution of 91.5% and 93% by surface-controlled mechanisms at 5 and 50 mV s−1 respectively. It also tackles the capacitive performance deterioration associated with thick electrodes, where a capacitance retention of 87% was observed when the mass loading was increased from 9.5 to 54.1 mg cm−2, corresponding a thickness increment from 1 to 6 mm. At the high mass loading of 54.1 mg cm−2, it managed to attain remarkable areal capacitance of 7.5 F cm−2. The assembled 3D architecture aerogel was also proven to be stable, demonstrating a capacitance retention of 97.1% after 10,000 cycles. Conclusively, constructing microstructured macrostructures emerges as an approach that sets the trend for future studies on developing 3D MXene architectures, possessing high potential to negate the seemingly insurmountable trade-off between areal/volumetric capacitance and rate performance. Additive manufacturing technologies, specifically EBP and DLP, provides promising avenues to optimize such 3D architectures owing to their high degree of freedom in designing such structures and precision in fabricating them. 6 Summary, challenges and future perspective MXene has taken a conspicuous place as a formidable electrochemically active material, which is the cornerstone to realize environmentally friendly, clean energy storage and utilization. It is endowed with excellent conductivity, hydrophilicity, and highly tunable chemical and structural diversity which give prospect for designing high performance supercapacitor, featuring high energy density, high power density and long cycle life. A multitude of mechanistic studies have been conducted to unravel the convoluted nature of charge storage process in MXene. It can be generally concluded that MXene shows EDLC behavior in H+-deficient electrolytes such as neutral and basic aqueous electrolytes. The presence of H+ ions allow facile protonation/deprotonation of oxygen-containing terminations on MXene, accompanied by variations in oxidation state of the “M” layer. Pseudocapacitance arose from these interactions offers considerably higher energy density than EDLC realized through physical ion adsorption. Therefore, tuning of the structural properties including interlayer spacing and lateral size, as well as surface functionalities are scrutinized to enhance pseudocapacitance in MXene. Conventional synthesis approaches like HF and in-situ HF etching are extremely hazardous to handle and would impart redox inactive -F terminations in the as-synthesized MXene, subverting redox activity. Alkali and molten salt etching are exceptional techniques to yield fluoride-free MXene but aggressive reaction conditions are seen as an inevitable requirement to attain commensurable effects. Halogen/interhalogen-based and electrochemical etching, thus, offer milder condition requirements. Novel approaches like thermal reduction etching, algae etching, wave-assisted etching and ionic liquid etching were further discovered that prioritize eco-friendliness and energy efficiency. Nevertheless, their as-synthesized MXene has yet to be explored for electrochemical properties, their implementation still needs further investigations, particularly on their reaction mechanisms and the resulting impacts on the MXene properties. Parallel with the propelling research on leveraging the common Ti3C2Tx MXene, new MXene species have been constantly discovered over the years, such as non-titanium-based counterparts of Mo2CTx, Nb3C2Tx, and V4C3Tx, and MXene with a double transition metals layer (e.g., Mo2TiC2Tx). Overall, it can be deduced that the nitride-based MXenes is favourable for supercapacitor electrode over carbide-based MXenes due to the enhanced metallic characteristics resulting from the presence of extra electrons in nitrogen [168]. Furthermore, bi-metallic MXenes outperform their mono-metallic counterparts due to the enhanced electrical conductivity resulting from the presence of multiple transition metal elements. Additionally, the significantly expanded interlayer spacing in bi-metallic MXenes promotes ion diffusion and transfer within electrolyte systems, thereby increasing the number of electrochemically active sites for efficient charge storage. With these advantages in mind, exploring multi-transition metal-based MXenes holds great promise for the future of supercapacitor technology. However, there are numerous theoretically predicted MXenes that have yet to be synthesized. Further effort is required in the discovery of new MAX phase structures to broaden the family of MXene and unveil more potential applications in electrochemical energy storage and conversion. The need to streamline synthesis techniques of nitride- and carbonitride-based MXene is impending as they potentially confer to higher capacitance due to enhanced electrical conductivity stemming from the presence of extra electron from the nitrogen atoms. In spite of the significant progress made in optimizing MXene synthesis methods for enhanced resulting properties, 2D MXene nanosheets with high surface energy are susceptible to agglomeration and restacking. The formation of MXene clusters with smaller surface areas results in longer ion transport path and low density of redox active sites. To avert this shortfall, the 2D MXene nanosheets have been designed to evolve towards 3D MXene architectures with a combination of characteristics that is conducive for both high-rate and high-volume charge storage. In summary, it is essential for an ideal 3D MXene structure to have the following properties working in synergy: (1) hierarchically porous network that maximizes the surface area of MXene nanosheets exposed to electrolyte for better accessibility of redox-active sites and greater active surface utilization; (2) vast amounts of interconnected pores that diminish ion transport hindrance to facilitate rapid omnidirectional ion diffusion between the interspaces of MXene nanosheets; (3) low tortuosity that eliminates redundant and lengthy ion transport pathways to allow high-rate operation of the as-fabricated electrodes; and (4) excellent conductive electron pathways to expedite efficient electron shuttling throughout the entire MXene structure via interconnected MXene nanosheets or addition of conductive spacers. However, the design of 3D MXene architectures often suffers from the trade-off between areal/volumetric capacitance and rate performance. Unidimensional architecturing experiences limited degree of freedom in varying the dimensions of structural fabrication, usually obtaining pores of homogeneous sizes. This bounds the resulting 3D architectures to either possess high areal/volumetric capacitance and low-rate performance, catering to applications such as renewable energy harvesting devices or vice versa, for applications that require short bursts of power like camera flash and power tools. The imminent development of wearable electronics with high-end functions such as smart watches and health monitoring devices drives the demand for ESSs that excel in both performance parameters, as they require high power output and device longevity. On that note, unidimensional architecturing strategies have reached its bottleneck and multidimensional architecturing sets the research direction for future studies, capable of realizing the unprecedented benefits of attaining “microstructured macrostructures”. The coupling of structures with varying dimensions presents the opportunity to challenge the status quo of the mentioned trade-off. The future development of 3D MXene architectures with increasing complexity is largely constraint by the resolution of additive manufacturing technologies. Although EBP provides an inexpensive and rapid method for fabricating freestanding macrostructures, its resolution is currently limited at ∼100 µm [169,170]. Hence, DLP presents an attractive alternative, with reported resolution up to ∼20 µm [171,172]. Technological advancement in higher resolution is beneficial to further reduce the dimensions of printed features, in order to fit in a macrostructure network with higher intricacy per unit area/volume for amplified electrochemical performance. Nonetheless, DLP has only been employed to fabricate templates as its shape forming mechanism relies on heavy chemical additives that essentially retards electrochemical activities. Studies directed towards formulating DLP printing inks with electrochemically active components are thus crucial. Beside tweaking the microscale structure, coupling MXene-based supercapacitors with RE-powered systems is a crucial way out for sustainable energy storage and utilization. The intermittency nature of RE give rise to irregular high energy surges, which can only be effectively captured by high-power density supercapacitors. As portable and wearable devices gained ubiquity nowadays, MXene-based supercapacitors offer greater advantages over other materials due to its superior flexibility that retains electrochemical activity under deformation. Nonetheless, there is a need for discerning a safer electrolyte rather than strong acid and alkali, which can jeopardize human life if leaked during bending. Ideally, more studies on surface termination and electrolyte ion matching are essential to realize novel pseudocapacitive mechanisms that do not necessarily rely on protonation/deprotonation mechanism, eliminating the common mandatory requirement of H2SO4 electrolyte. On top of this, the partial oxidation of MXene due to dissolved oxygen in an aqueous electrolyte can hinder the charge storage performance. The solid electrolyte or transparent gel polymer electrolyte, which allowed significant deformation, can be considered to extend the lifetime of a MXene-based supercapacitor. Upon remediating the innate challenges of fabricating practical, high performance MXene-based supercapacitor, the next question in mind is its potential for large scale manufacturing. There is an emergence of studies aiming at discovering novel MXene synthesis methods that emphasize on production scaling practicality, where a yield of ∼1 kg was successfully attained via etching with supercritical carbon dioxide [173,174]. Nonetheless, the proofs-of-concept in terms of systematic production scalability, provided by these studies were relatively shallow, such that there remain possible underlying problems that must be realized and mitigated. For example, the etching reaction of MAX phase is exothermic by nature, performing it under supercritical environment may cause problematic process heat management. The generation of high temperature, high pressure localities due to inhomogeneous exothermic release not only causes localized oxidation of the MXene product, but also creates overwhelming burden onto the process equipment, leading to costly construction and maintenance fee [175,176]. Thus far, there has only been one study that featured in-depth analysis for the scaling up of Ti3C2TX MXene synthesis, from 1 to 50 g per batch [52]. Despite the study showing indifferent characteristics of MXene synthesized from either batch, issues potentially arising from further scaling up to pilot scale remain unexplored. As discussed above, properties of the MXene product depend heavily on the etching reaction kinetics. Homogeneity of MAX phase particle size and reaction heat distribution are of primary concerns to prevent overetching or incomplete etching in different localities [177]. In terms of process safety, there lies the hazard of metal powder ignition during the synthesis of MAX phase as well as the notorious evolution of HF vapor due to excess exothermic release [178]. However, these issues can be tackled methodically by process engineering such as enclosing MAX phase synthesis reactions in highly inert environment, regulating reaction exothermic release by controlling the feeding rate of MAX phase or directing intense research studies into uncovering the large-scale potential of HF-free synthesis techniques. Regardless of the countless studies showing the attractive prospects of MXene in a broad spectrum of applications beyond energy storage, there is a disproportionate lack of research interest in venturing into scaling up its synthesis and fabrication technologies. A possible reason is that, another hurdle to be tackled is its storage inconvenience and shelf-life limitations. Degradation mechanism of MXene nanosheets and its mitigation strategies have been proposed such as nanosheet edge passivation and optimized storage in organic solvents. However, the complexity of these methods coupled with the numerous concerns present in the upstream processes significantly hamper the reward-to-effort ratio of MXene production [179,180]. While it is crucial to streamline upstream processes, it is equally vital to consider the industrialization of application-driven fabrication. The maturity of downstream processes will generate a steady demand flux for MXene, in turn, placing immense pressure to push the advancements of large-scale upstream technologies. There have been several studies demonstrating the development of scalable methodologies for the fabrication of strong, highly conductive Ti3C2Tx MXene films, but such studies are still non-existent for the fabrication of MXene with 3D architectures [181,182]. A wide range of ingenious methods to construct 3D MXene architectures have been highlighted in this review, but a portion of them involve meticulous procedures and may have low practical value for industrialization. In conclusion, it is recommended that parallel research attention should be given towards both performance enhancement and large-scale practicality when conducting studies on constructing novel architectures for the fabrication of MXene-based supercapacitor electrodes. On that note, the incorporation of additive manufacturing technologies presents a promising direction towards achieving both aspects, ultimately positioning 3D MXene architecture-based supercapacitors at the frontier of ESS studies at both the research and industrial level. Wen Jie Yiang received his Bachelor of Engineering majoring in new energy science and engineering with Honors from Xiamen University, Malaysia in 2022. He is currently a postgraduate research student at the School of Energy and Chemical Engineering at Xiamen University, Malaysia under the supervision of Dr. Chuan Yi Foo. His current research interests include flexible supercapacitor, and MXene-based supercapacitor. Wee-Jun Ong received his B.Eng. and Ph.D. degrees in chemical engineering from Monash University. He is an associate professor and Assistant Dean in School of Energy and Chemical Engineering at Xiamen University Malaysia. Starting from 2021, he becomes a director of “CONNECT” research center. Previously, he was a scientist at Agency for Science, Technology and Research (A*STAR), Singapore. In 2019, he was a visiting scientist at Technische Universität Dresden and a visiting professor at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory. His research interests include nanomaterials for energy storage devices, photocatalytic, photoelectrocatalytic, and electrochemical H2O splitting, CO2 reduction and N2 fixation. Pau-Loke Show received his BSc. degree and Ph.D. degree from Universiti Putra Malaysia. He is a Full Professor at the Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Faculty of Science and Engineering, University of Nottingham Malaysia. In the year of 2022, he is elected as a Fellow of IChemE (FIChemE). He is currently a Professional Engineer (PEng) registered with the Board of Engineers Malaysia, Fellow of the Engineering Council UK (CEng), Cooperate Member of The Institution of Engineers, and Professional Technologies (PTech) registered with the Malaysia Board of Technologists. Chuan Yi Foo received his BSc. degree and Ph.D. degree from Universiti Putra Malaysia (2015 and 2018, respectively). He worked as a postdoc at Xiamen University Malaysia and currently an Assistant Professor in New Energy Science and Engineering at Xiamen University Malaysia since 2019. He is particularly interested in unravelling the potential and workability of advanced manufacturing technology in nanomaterials fabrication, as well as improve the performance of current electrochemical energy storagedevices.

coredata.dc:description: MXene has been the limelight for studies on electrode active materials, aiming at developing supercapacitors with boosted energy density to meet the emerging influx of wearable and portable electronic devices. Despite its various desirable properties including intrinsic flexibility, high specific surface area, excellent metallic conductivity and unique abundance of surface functionalities, its full potential for electrochemical performance is hindered by the notorious restacking phenomenon of MXene nanosheets. Ascribed to its two-dimensional (2D) nature and surface functional groups, inevitable Van der Waals interactions drive the agglomeration of nanosheets, ultimately reducing the exposure of electrochemically active sites to the electrolyte, as well as severely lengthening electrolyte ion transport pathways. As a result, energy and power density deteriorate, limiting the application versatility of MXene-based supercapacitors. Constructing 3D architectures using 2D nanosheets presents as a straightforward yet ingenious approach to mitigate the fatal flaws of MXene. However, the sheer number of distinct methodologies reported, thus far, calls for a systematic review that unravels the rationale behind such 3D MXene structural designs. Herein, this review aims to serve this purpose while also scrutinizing the structure–property relationship to correlate such structural modifications to their ensuing electrochemical performance enhancements. Besides, the physicochemical properties of MXene play fundamental roles in determining the effective charge storage capabilities of 3D MXene-based electrodes. This largely depends on different MXene synthesis techniques and synthesis condition variations, hence, elucidated in this review as well. Lastly, the challenges and perspectives for achieving viable commercialization of MXene-based supercapacitor electrodes are highlighted.
